In November 1919, Calvin Coolidge was re-elected governor of Massachusetts, s. The Washington herald., November 05, 1919, Image 1, col. 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1919-11-05/ed-...

Negative has a date of 8/3/23, but that is a likely re-use, dating as it does to the day after Warren G. Harding died and VP Calvin Coolidge became president (he was notified and sworn in as President at the family farm). There are a number of photos of Coolidge (as Massachusetts governor) milking cows at his father's farm in Plymouth Notch, VT. Here is one published in a newspaper in July, 1920: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84031081/1920-07-31/ed-...

Bailie John Connel King (A bailie or baillie is a civic officer in the local government of Scotland, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bailie): "Bailie John King of Glasgow founded the Keppoch Iron Works with his father in 1873. By the 1890's the plant covered over eight acres of land and employed over five hundred workers. In addition to being a successful business man, John King was a keen philanthropist and member of numerous societies and groups. Among other activities he was Director of the Canal Boatmen's Mission, Clerk of Free St. Paul's Church, a Rechabite, a Freemason, Director of the Scottish National Sabbath School Union, President of the Lodging House Workers' Union and a Director of Grove Street Institute. In 1897 he became a Magistrate and four years later, in 1901, Senior Magistrate; a role that, in conjunction with his position as Chairman of the Licensing Court, gained him further public acclaim. " www.bonhams.com/auctions/20653/lot/71/ Member of British delegation to 1919 International Trade Conference, see

The Independent, Volume 100, Dec 20, 1919 books.google.com/books?id=jYRAAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA247&l... reported that Baron Romano Avezzano was the new Italian ambassador to the United States. But based on the photo of the Baroness beside her husband, this is likely a photo from long before 1919 or a different baroness. According to New-York tribune., March 21, 1920, Page 7, Image 85, central panel with photos. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-03-21/ed-... the wife of Baron Romano Avezzano was the former Marie Jacqueline Taylor of St. Louis.
Baron Avezzano is at

The correct spelling is Romano Avezzana, s. it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camillo_Romano_Avezzana "Romano Avezzana" seems to be the family name, only Camillo is the given name, s. asisp.intesasanpaolo.com/intesa-web/detail/bci/IT-ISP-AS0...

This photo shows probably Yolanda Romano Avezzana, the daughter of the Italian ambassador, s. photo in The news scimitar., February 13, 1920, 4th EDITION, Image 16 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn98069867/1920-02-13/ed-... and in The Sun and the New York herald., February 15, 1920, Section 5 Pictorial Section, Image 59 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030273/1920-02-15/ed-...

I agree this is a possibility. I've been unable to decide. The alternative would be a photo from 1900 or so of Jacqueline Marie Taylor -- or Marie Jacqueline Taylor (I've found both orders) -- or recently married as baroness. I think I see an engagement ring. See www.pinterest.se/pin/56787645272256269/ for a photo said to be from around 1900.

I think the photo on pinterest shows clearly the baroness, but there she is considerably older than the woman on the Bain photo (and the caption doesn't mean that the photo was taken around 1900, but that she had married around 1900 IMO.) The photos in the Clearwater Republican., March 12, 1920, Image 6 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86091128/1920-03-12/ed-... or in The news scimitar., February 13, 1920 (s. above) show her not (much) older IMO. But I agree that the Bain photo could be an older one of her, since I didn't find any other photos picturing her when she was young (and the daughter seems to look a bit different, see e.g. photo in The Washington times., November 30, 1919, FINAL EDITION, Page 11 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1919-11-30/ed-...)
Thanks swanq and B-59 for spelling help- we will update our records.

The Ansaldo SVA (named for Savoia-Verduzio-Ansaldo) was a family of Italian reconnaissance biplane aircraft of World War I and the decade after. Originally conceived as a fighter, the SVA was found inadequate for that role. Nevertheless, its impressive speed, range and operational ceiling, with its top speed making it one of the fastest (if not the fastest) of all Allied combat aircraft in World War I, gave it the right properties to be an excellent reconnaissance aircraft and even light bomber. Production of the aircraft continued well after the war, with the final examples delivered in 1918. Two minor variants were produced, one with reconnaissance cameras, the other without cameras but extra fuel tanks.
Probably the start of the transcontinental air race on October 8, 1919. See

The Ansaldo SVA (named for Savoia-Verduzio-Ansaldo) was a family of Italian reconnaissance biplane aircraft of World War I and the decade after. Originally conceived as a fighter, the SVA was found inadequate for that role. Nevertheless, its impressive speed, range and operational ceiling, with its top speed making it one of the fastest (if not the fastest) of all Allied combat aircraft in World War I, gave it the right properties to be an excellent reconnaissance aircraft and even light bomber. Production of the aircraft continued well after the war, with the final examples delivered in 1918. Two minor variants were produced, one with reconnaissance cameras, the other without cameras but extra fuel tanks.

This must be on or before October 8, 1919, since on that day the Brattleboro Daily Reformer, page 8 column 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86071593/1919-10-08/ed-... reported that Brandt was killed and Nevitt injured in a bi-plane accident. The [New York] Sun., October 09, 1919, page 1, top of column 6 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1919-10-09/ed-... reports that Nevitt was killed while Brandt was seriously injured. The evening world., October 08, 1919, Final Edition, Page 20 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1919-10-08/ed-... includes this pair in a list of pilots and passengers starting from New York (Roosevelt Field, Mineola) in the air race across the continent. Air Corps Information Circular, Issues 2-82 books.google.com/books?id=QdBRAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA21&lp... Probably a more reliable source than the newspapers, this states that it was Nevitt who was killed on October 8, 1919 at Deposit, NY. It spells the colonel's name as Brant.

Aircraft Journal of January 1919 books.google.com/books?id=y0o_AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA72&lp... has a picture of Brant. A bio in Aviation and Aircraft Journal, Volume 10, from 1921 books.google.com/books?id=UY9MAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA690&l... proves that he survived. Later bio at www.af.mil/About-Us/Biographies/Display/Article/108024/ma... and his findagrave site forums.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=472...

The race is described in Aviation in the U.S. Army, 1919-1939 books.google.com/books?id=E1gGW_TqLawC&pg=PA30&lp... The course to San Francisco from New York went via Buffalo, Cleveland, Chicago, Omaha, Cheyenne, Salt Lake City, and Reno. Nevitt's death is confirmed on page 31. Another account of the race is in United States Air Services, Volume 2 books.google.com/books?id=DM87AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA2-PA7&...

Thanks for sorting out what happened in this dramatic story, referring to useful resources, and pointing out the varying spellings of Brant's name. The Library of Congress also has it as "Brant" ( lccn.loc.gov/n2010067667 ). We'll add and adjust information when we update the description.

The pilot is Lt. Howard D. Norris (US Army Air Service). See: Page 206, Army List and Directory - February 1921 Unfortunately, there's little I can find on "H.J. Meyer", other than he flew with Norris as the Mechanic for the DH-4 they crewed during the 1919 Transcontinental Air Race. Although reportedly only slightly injured while flying westward in the race, their aircraft would crash into a hill on October 13, 1919 approximately nine miles from Oconto, Nebraska as they attempted to land. ("Plane No. 37 Falls To Earth Near Oconto," Page 7, The Ogden Standard (Ogden, Utah), October 13, 1919)

The man talking to King Albert in this picture (at right) is probably Rodman Wanamaker. See

This might be the NOMA, returned to her owner Vincent Astor in July 1919 after service as USS NOMA (SP-131) See navalwarfare.blogspot.com/2008/04/uss-noma-sp-131.html But the Topeka State Journal., October 03, 1919, Page 11, column 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016014/1919-10-03/ed-... is one of several copies of a piece that says the royal party arrived at the Battery on the Rodman Wanamaker yacht Noma, before they traveled in "motors" to City Hall. Indeed, it is the same yacht. NYT of September 28, 1919 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E05E2DA1638EF31A... reported that Wanamaker had bought the yacht from Astor -- just in time to host the King and Queen of Belgium. The Noma was a sister ship to one Wanamaker had owned but was destroyed by fire.

Gavin McNab Dies In San Francisco. San Francisco, California; December 28, 1937. Gavin McNab is dead. Probably the best known lawyer in San Francisco, famous throughout the nation for his legal attainments, his wit and knowledge of human nature, as well as for his vigorous political activities. He was 64 years of age — at the height of his power. Death came yesterday noon without warning, either to himself or to his friends. He died alone, sitting at his desk in his office on the twelfth floor of the United Bank building. Only an hour before he had been dictating to his confidential secretary, who left him at noon, to return and find that "the chief’’ had passed away, alone. cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=HT19271229.2.8

Edward William Bok (born Eduard Willem Gerard Cesar Hidde Bok[1]) (October 9, 1863 – January 9, 1930)[1] was a Dutch-born American editor and Pulitzer Prize-winning author. Bok is credited with coining the term living room as the name for a room of a house that had commonly been called the parlor or drawing room. He also created Bok Tower Gardens in central Florida.

Ford Ashman Carpenter (1868 - 1947), meteorologist, aeronaut, author, and photographer socialarchive.iath.virginia.edu/ark:/99166/w67101pq www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=116239785 The Bemidji daily pioneer., December 06, 1919, Page 2 (and other newspapers) printed this photo, s. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86063381/1919-12-06/ed-...

The Bemidji daily pioneer caption:

"HAS UNIQUE JOB

Dr. Ford A. Carpenter of Los Angeles has the distinction of filling the only position of its kind in the United States. He is head of the newly established department of meteorology
and aeronautics in the Los Angeles chamber of commerce.
He resigned after 31 years in the government weather bureau service to apply his knowledge of climatic conditions to the better development of agriculture, horticulture and aerial navi
gation, through practical application of established facts of atmospheric conditions.  
In engaging Doctor Carpenter to head its new department, the chamber becomes active in the development of aerial navigation. Climatic conditions in southern California are such that it is believed that that section of the country will equal any in transportation by air. The new department will co-operate with the two government aviation fields and the balloon school
that are situated in the vicinity of Los Angeles."

The photographer: "Ian Pirie MacDonald (January 27, 1867 – April 22, 1942) was an American portrait photographer, New York City civic leader, and peace advocate. He photographed over 70,000 men in the span of his career, including international heads of state, religious leaders, and artists. Born in Chicago, MacDonald moved to Hudson, New York in 1883, where he worked as a photographer's apprentice prior to opening his own studio in Albany. Upon gaining a reputation in portraiture, MacDonald made the decision to only photograph men, a decision that even applied to family photos, and from that point on dubbed himself "Pirie MacDonald – Photographer of Men". His prolific body of work encompasses many well-known men of the early to mid-20th century including Spencer Trask, Woodrow Wilson, William Ralph Inge, Seán O'Casey and Antoine Lumiére, all of which were taken within New York City save for Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk and Christian X of Denmark." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pirie_MacDonald

'Red Cross officials were notified today by the War Department that more than 150,000 pieces of lost baggage belonging to former officers and men of the American Expeditionary forces, are stored on the Government docks at Hoboken. Much of the baggage is marked with names only and cannot be forwarded to the owners. In all cases a new shipping address Is required. As the Red Cross desires to assist each man from overseas to recover his lost property as well as to help the Government dispose of this enormous accumulation of property, owners of lost baggage are asked to forward their claims and addresses to the 'Lost Baggage Branch. Pershing Leads WWI Victory Parade "On September 10, 1919, nearly a year after World War I ended, Gen. John J. Pershing led a victory parade down New York City’s Fifth Avenue. Vast crowds cheered as 25,000 U.S. soldiers who had served in the American Expeditionary Force’s 1st Division on the Western Front marched from 107th Street to Washington Square in Greenwich Village, wearing trench helmets and full combat gear.
'New York lived yesterday probably the last chapter in its history of great military spectacles growing out of the war,' The New York Times reported. The loudest cheers were for Pershing, who, according to the Times, 'was kept at almost continual salute by the tributes volleyed at him from both sides of the avenue.'
"By the time an armistice was declared on Nov. 11, 1918, more than 2 million American soldiers had served on the battlefields of Western Europe. Roughly 50,000 of them were killed in action. "In September 1919, Congress authorized President Woodrow Wilson to promote Pershing, the commander of the expeditionary force, to the rank of General of the Armies of the United States. He remains the sole person to be promoted in his own lifetime to the highest rank in the U.S. Army. "Congress also authorized Pershing to create his own insignia. He chose to wear four gold stars for the rest of his career, which meant he outranked subsequent Army chiefs of staff, who wore four silver stars, and even the five-star General of the Army insignias worn during World War II by George Marshall, Douglas MacArthur and Dwight Eisenhower. "Pershing led a similar victory parade down Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington on Sept. 17. On Sept. 19, he addressed a joint session of the Congress. He died in 1948 at age 87." Sources: The New York Times; History.com – Andrew Glass, Politico Street view (2016) 5th Avenue at West 14th St

Interestingly, Cantor is standing on the top hatch and turret of an M1917 Light Tank, the American license-built version of the French Renault FT-17 Tank (the M1917 is distinguished from the FT-17 by the lifting hook on the hull, noted on the photo above). Presumably the tank was in Columbus Circle for a postwar display. Here's a photo of an M1917 Light Tank posted at the Boston Public Library's Flickr collection for comparison: www.flickr.com/photos/boston_public_library/8780208403/

This is probably singer Grace Cameron, who in September, 1919 sued for an annulment of her marriage: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9504E2DF153AE0... She is listed as having been in a number of shows between 1900 and 1908 at the Internet Broadway Database site: www.ibdb.com/broadway-cast-staff/grace-cameron-34331 Here she is singing a comic song from 1912: www.youtube.com/watch?v=_PyPW5pO2YE There is a short biographical sketch in a YouTube posting: " By 1909, the Edison company ceased the practice of opening records with spoken introductions (such intros were common as late as 1908). Grace Cameron was born on August 1, 1879 (with the name Grace Kerr) in Storm Lake, Iowa. The comic singer joined the famous touring group called The Bostonians and was in Robin Hood, playing the role of Maid Marian. She recorded five titles issued on two-minute Edison Standard cylinders and four issued on four-minute wax Amberols. "Adam and Eve" (Amberol 136) and "Whose Baby Girl Are You?" (Standard 10265) had been introduced by Cameron in the 1908 show The Pied Piper. She was probably a mezzo-soprano though Edison literature identified her only as "comedienne." Her single Columbia disc featured "Since Dolly Dimples Made A Hit" backed by "I'll Bet I'd Be A Riot Down On Broadway" (A1205), recorded on July 11, 1912. "Since Dolly Dimples Made A Hit," with lyrics by William Jerome and music by Jean Schwartz, is from the 1904 musical Piff! Paff! Pouf!, which was produced by F.C. Whitney for the Casino Theater in New York and starred Eddie Foy, with Cameron cast as one of his daughters. In telling of Dolly, the song alludes to many topical events and stage personalities--Lillian Russell, David Belasco, Charlie Frohman, Leslie Carter, Duse. Dolly is a mere chorus-girl in a musical comedy, but because its author gave Dolly a few lines to speak, she behaves as though she is the show's star: Dolly Dimples in the chorus She had served her time. She joined it when Kirlafy Brothers They were in their prime. She carried a spear For many a year. Contented in the back row With her eighteen per a week Until the night the author Handed her a line to speak And little Dolly Dimples made a hit. Since Dolly Dimples made a hit There's been an awful change. Her mother really wouldn't know her now. She gives the other girls the icy bow... In the June 1970 issue of Hobbies, Jim Walsh reports that she was the first theatrical performer to pay, in 1905, for advertising in Variety. The date of her death is unknown. Walsh states in the August 1973 issue of Hobbies that Cameron was said to be living in Long Beach, California, in retirement in the early 1960s." www.youtube.com/watch?v=TJwRsGKuhUU

C. W. Russell (Charles W. Russell, Charles Wells Russell, Hon. Charles Wells Russell) (1856-1927) was an American lawyer, author and poet. He was a son of Charles Wells Russell (1818-1867) and Margaret Wilson (Moore) Russell. His father was a prominent Confederate States of America politician during the American Civil War. He graduated from Georgetown University with a Master of Laws in 1884. Charles married Lucy Floyd Mosby in 1879. After her death he married her sister Lelia James Mosby in 1885. They had three children, John W. Russell, Margaret Moore Russell (Mosby) and Lucy Virginia Russell. Lucy married Alfred James Ogster in 1917. He was the British Consul in Galveston, Texas. C. W. Russell entered the Department of Justice, Washington in 1886. He was a U.S. Assistant Attorney General and U.S. Minister to Persia (1909-14). He successfully argued many French spoliation cases, the Maine explosion case and was involved with many Panama Canal issues. Charles W. Russell wrote a play "Cuba Libre" and four collections of poems, including "The Secret Place and Other Poems" (1911) and "Iranian Rest and Other Lyrics" (1912). He also edited the "Memoirs of Colonel John Singleton Mosby" (his brother-in-law) in 1917. In the news:  It could be this photograph was in the news in August and September of 1919 as details of the Versailles Treaty were being hammered out in an attempt to have it ratified by Congress. President Wilson was fundamentally opposed to any changes that would send the treaty back to Paris. Among many other issues, there were protests from Hungary, Albania, and Persia. C. W. Russell, former American Minister to Persia spoke before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee saying that the Anglo-Persian Treaty robbed Persia of much of her sovereignty. Senator Philander C. Knox, former Secretary of State pushed for the right of self determination of Persia. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] There is an additional photograph of Charles W. Russell in the C.M. Bell Studio Collection at The Library of Congress.

John T. Pratt  (John Teele Pratt) (1873-1927) was a son of Charles Pratt (1830-1891) and his second wife Helen Richardson (Mary Helen Richardson) (1839-1907).  He graduated from Amherst College and Harvard Law School. He was an industrialist with Standard Oil Co. and a philanthropist. In 1917, perhaps the time this photo was in the news, Mr. Pratt went to Washington and established the National Budget Commission. He urged a national budget system before the House Appropriations Committee who adopted it. During the later part of 1918, he served as a Major in the American Red Cross at Paris. He married Ruth Sears Baker (1877-1965). Mrs. Ruth Baker Pratt was the first woman to represent New York City on the Board of Alderman and later the first woman to represent New York in Congress (17th Congressional District 1929-33.) They had three daughters and two sons: Mrs. Virginia Thayer (1905-1979),  Mrs. Sally Jackson (Sally Sears Pratt) (1908-1973),  Mrs. Phyllis Nitze (1912-1987),  Edwin Baker Pratt (Edwin Howard Baker Pratt) (1913-1975), and John T. Pratt, Jr. (John Teele Pratt, Jr.) (1903-1969)   [1] [2] [3] [4]

T. W. Sims (Thetus W. Sims, Thetus Willrette Sims, Honorable Thetus W. Sims) (1852-1939) was an American politician (Democrat) and served 12 terms as a member of the United States House of Representatives for the 8th congressional district of Tennessee. He graduated from the law department of Cumberland University, Lebanon, Tennessee, in 1876. Sims married Nannie "Nannie" Kitrell Sims (1855-1946) and they had seven children. Sims was an important advocate for the nineteenth amendment which gave women the right to vote. Tennessee was also the last state to ratify the nineteenth amendment. He pushed for the Sims Act, which forbade interstate transportation of fight films, primarily boxing after the Johnson v Flynn fight in 1912. The act was known as the first time Congress took censorship action in regards to films and remained on the books until 1940. – Photograph: Edmonston, Washington, DC  [1] [2] [3] [4] [5]

In April, 1913 – the time period this photograph could have been in the news – Congressman T. W. Sims was assaulted in Farragut Square [Washington, DC] by Charles C. Glover, President of the Riggs National Bank, one of the most prominent men in Washington financial and social circles. "The assault was the outcome of criticism directed at Mr. Glover by Mr. Sims on the floor of the House of Representatives [four years earlier] in connection with Mr. Glover's effort to sell to the government a large tract of land adjoining Rock Creek Park [in Washington]. Mr. Glover said,
"I looked at him squarely in the face and said, "I want to tell you to your face that you are a contemptible liar, yes, a miserable contemptible liar. Furthermore, I mean to show you just what I think of you.' "With that, I struck Sims a blow squarely on the jaw..."
While Congressman Sims did not press the matter a congressional investigation was begun a few days later. Ultimately, the matter was resolved when Speaker of the House James "Champ" Clark (D-Mo.) issued a warrant for Glover’s arrest and reprimanded the banker on the House floor.
"If one person is permitted to go unpunished for an assault upon a Congressman, everybody can assault a Congressman for words used in debate on the floor of the House, and free speech is at an end", Clark said just before he released Glover.
[As an FYI aside, any speech made by an elected legislator – from a town meeting/city council member to a member of the U.S. Congress, on the floor of that respective body is protected speech, and is not subject to any action for libel, slander, defamation, etc.] "Yet Glover eventually had the last word in land preservation. For example, one bill he lobbied for finally passed Congress in a compromise that created the National Zoo, a more popular possibility among Members, and opened the door to a commission that established Rock Creek Park. It was just one of the many fights Glover fought on behalf of the District. In fact, Glover, after whom Glover Park was named, went on to help create a city that would be very different today had he not played his part."  [1] [2] [3] [4] [5]

David Edmonston (D. B. Edmonston, David B Edmonston) (b.1860), the photographer of Congressman Sims' portrait operated Edmonton's Studio at 1407 F Street NW, in Washington, D.C. from 1916-1924. [1]  (There is a photograph of 1407 F Street NW, in the May 6, 1911 edition of The Washington Times in The Library of Congress Chronicling America collection. The text refers to the buildings as acquired by Col. O.G. Staples from the estate of Miss Cruit, and reports Col. Staples will remodel both of them.) Edmonston photographed an impressive number of prominent men and women during a short period of time. In addition to photographs of President Wilson holding his first grandchild, Francis Sayre and Charles A. Lindbergh as a young man with his father, Edmonston has more than forty photographs of prominent women in the Women of Protest Collection at The Library of Congress, including a photograph of Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton. This also tells me that because Edmonston was active from 1916-1924, my l-o-n-g-i-s-h post about Mr Sims being smacked in the face in 1913 likely wasn't the reason he was "in the news" at the time of this photograph's publication -- so it's back to the drawing board.     LOC - add Edmonston as creator/contributor?

It appears that this couple were married in the air on July 26, 1919. The couple were in one plane and the minister in another, communicating by radio. The two planes were flying over Sheepshead Bay Speedway. Guests below had radios too. See Hamilton Literary Magazine books.google.com/books?id=dR8_AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA29&lp... and New-York tribune., July 27, 1919, page 1, column 2 (halfway down) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1919-07-27/ed-...
Great find, swanq- what an interesting story!

This shot may well have been taken 26 July 1919 on the second day of the NYPD Field Games at Sheepshead Bay Speedway.  The events that day featured the marriage of Lt George Burgess and Miss Emily Schaeffer of Sea Gate, Long Island in planes flying at 3,000 ft.  The ceremonies were transmitted to the crowd below by that "ultra-modern" device, the radio telegraph.  

It is noted in press accounts of the day that Gov. Smith and Mayor Hyland were in attendance.

Striking cast members of the Broadway show "At 9:45" parade down Broadway in the Actor's Parade on August 18, 1919. The banner suggests 100% of the company supports the strike by Actor's Equity Association. Actors joined by stage managers, stagehands, chorus girls, musicians, variety artists and musical artists went on strike forcing shows all over the country to shut down. It was one of the most significant strikes in labor history as it reshaped the definition of labor.
"The parade of the actors down Broadway was staged despite the drizzling rain, which kept down the numbers of those along the line of the march but did not in any way affect the numbers or spirits of those in the procession. It was led by Major Reginald Barlow and several hundred actors who had served overseas, many of them in uniform."  [1]
The biggest stars of the time locked arms with their lesser known brethren – several thousand strong – and paraded down Broadway in full solidarity. The parade kicked off a week of benefit performances for Equity at the Lexington Avenue Opera House. Eventually, the producers had no choice but to recognize Actors' Equity Association (AEA) as the bargaining agent for their performers.   [2]

"At 9:45", by Owen Davis was performed at the Playhouse Theatre on Broadway, June 28 - October 1, 1919. It starred George Backus (1857-1939), Clifford Dempsey (1865-1938), Madeleine King and Noel Tearle who are likely shown parading in this photograph. Other members of the company (who may be in this photograph) were Idalene Cotton, Marie Goff, Harry Green, Nedda Harrigan, John Harrington, Frank Hatch, Frank Hilton, Peter Lang, Leo Mielziner, Gustave Rolland, Edith Shayne, and Robert Thorne. "At 9:45" was directed by John Cromwell. This photograph is looking north on Broadway between 37th and 38th St. The bottom of the sign ("ANDIE") for the Hotel Normandie can be seen top, leftish. (This view was likely taken from the 2nd floor of the Regal Shoe Store at the corner of 37th Street). Just beyond the Hotel Normandie is the Casino Theater (1882-1929), said to be the best example of Moorish architecture in the country. It was the first theatre with a roof garden, the first to be entirely lit by electricity, and the first to feature a chorus line – the Floradora Girls, who included Evelyn Nesbit, over whom Harry K. Thaw murdered Stanford White (1853-1906). [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6]

In August 1919, actors joined by stage managers, stagehands, chorus girls, musicians, variety artists and musical artists went on strike forcing shows all over the country to shut down. It was one of the most significant strikes in labor history as it reshaped the definition of labor. On a rainy August 18th afternoon the biggest stars of the time locked arms with their lesser known brethren – several thousand strong – and paraded down Broadway in full solidarity. "The parade of the actors down Broadway was staged despite the drizzling rain, which kept down the numbers of those along the line of the march but did not in any way affect the numbers or spirits of those in the procession. It was led by Major Reginald Barlow and several hundred actors who had served overseas, many of them in uniform." The parade kicked off a week of benefit performances for Equity at the Lexington Avenue Opera House. Eventually, the producers had no choice but to recognize Actors' Equity Association (AEA) as the bargaining agent for their performers.  [1] [2]

Hana Shimozumi (Mme. Hana Shimozumi, Mme. Hana Shimozumi Iki) (1893-1978) was a Japanese prima donna singing the role of Yum Yum in Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Mikado" with the new Gallo English Opera Company. It was scheduled to open on Labor Day, September 1, 1919 at the Shubert Theatre, New York City for two weeks before going on a tour of the United States and Canada. Hana was born in Honolulu, brought up in an American family in San Francisco and educated at Stanford University. Her vocal study was with Mrs. A.F. Bridge. –excerpted from The New York Times, [1] The Musicians and Stagehands Unions went on strike at 7:00PM, September 1, 1919, which delayed the opening of "The Mikado" for a week. When it did give it's first performance on September 8, 1919, both Hana Shimozumi and the production received a glowing review in The New York Times.  [2] [3] She later sang Fire Fly and Madame Butterfly and was a star with the San Carlos Opera Company and the Gallo English Comic Opera.   Mme. Shimozumi gave up a promising operatic career when she married Dr. G Iki (George S. Iki) (1892-1974) a surgeon, and a University of California graduate, of Sacramento. They had a daughter Marsha Y. Iki (b.1922). [4] [5] After the United States entered World War II, Hana Iki, her husband, daughter and three other family members were forcibly relocated and interned at Tule Lake Relocation Center in Newell, California in 1942. Hana was a U.S. Citizen, born in Honolulu County, Hawaii. She attended public schools in San Francisco, had never been to Japan, and didn't speak, read or write Japanese. [6]

SINGERS OF VATICAN                                     HERE FOR CONCERTS "Four soloists from the Sistine Chapel Choir of the Vatican, Rome, including the only adult male soprano and male contralto in the choir, arrived yesterday for a four months' tour of this country.  The tour was arranged by special permission of the Vatican and the Italian Government. "The soloists are Allesandro Gabrielli, soprano; Luigi Gentili, contralto; Ezio Cecchini, tenor, and Augusto Dos Santos, basso. Their accompanist is Albert Cammetti. Their tour, which has been arranged by a musical bureau, opens in Carnegie Hall, Sept. 14 [1919].  They have permission to be away from Rome until Jan. 1. They will give seventy-five concerts. "The coming of the Italian church singers is an event of great interest in musical circles, since it is the first appearance here of singers from the Sistine Choir.  This choir is composed of thirty-two choral chaplains, whose special privilege it is to appear at the ecclesiastical functions at which the Pope appears in person.  Some of the music which will be sung in America was written in the fourth century. – New York Times, Aug 20, 1919

The caption of a photo in the Evening times-Republican., August 27, 1919, Image 2 gives the name of four of the singers as Luigi Centilli, Ezio Cecchini, Don Santos Anguste and Albert Cauretti. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85049554/1919-08-27/ed-...

The Royal Navy (modified) Courageous-class battlecruiser HMS Furious, as initially completed with its flight deck (for launching and recovering aircraft) forward of its superstructure while retaining a single 18-inch gun turret aft. This arrangement for operating aircraft was unwieldy as it sounds, so in converting the ship into an aircraft carrier in November 1917 the aft turret was removed and an additional flight deck was added aft of the superstructure. The Royal Navy quickly came to the realization that an aircraft carrier featuring two separate flight decks separated by an immense superstructure in the middle was not an optimal arrangement. Accordingly, HMS Furious would undergo a much more significant conversion and re-build between June 1921 and September 1925. This was made possible by the removal of her superstructure. She'd serve the Royal Navy up until September 1944, when her age and the delivery of much more capable purpose-built escort and full-size aircraft carriers made her redundant. See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Furious_(47)

cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=LAH19200323.2.204 LA Herald 23 March 1920 PRINCESS DELLA PATTRA OF EGYPT AND FILM COLONY KHEDIVE’S NIECE GUILTLESS IN JEWEL CASE After considering charges by Erich Buehle, who claimed to have given her $6000 in money and valuable jewels in Los Angeles when she planned to enter motion picture work, the San Francisco grand jury today failed to indict Princess Della Pattra, reputed niece of a former khedive of Egypt. The princess is well known in Los Angeles, having lived at a fashionable hotel while in the city. She is said to have won many admirers here. Buehle charged that he advanced the princess some $6000 in cash and valuable jewels. He declared that she told him she was to star in a motion picture production depicting life in Egypt and that it was for this purpose that he furnished her with the funds. Buehle said he advanced the money while they were in this city. The grand jury, after hearing the story, refused to indict the princess. She Is said to be at present in New York city.

In June 1920 (see date on negative), she was in the news again. She was arrested and charged with embezzlement. See The Cook County news-herald., June 30, 1920, page 2, with picture at lower left chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83016544/1920-06-30/ed-... 'Princess Dalla Pattra Hassan el Kmmel of Alexandria, Egypt, who is under arrest in New York charged with embezzling $7,000 from E. Buehler, a San Francisco engineer. The Princess has been in the United States about a year and recently she engaged in motion picture work. She is said to be a niece otf the Khedive of Egypt. Her arrest came as a shock to many who knew her in New York and San Francisco. The Princess said that Buehler fell in love with her and offered to finance her to any extent if she would marry him. To show his sincerity she continued, he advanced $7,000. "It was all perfectly, legitimate. There was no embezzlement" she added.'

Ada Jones (Ada Jane Jones) (1873-1922) was a popular singer who made her first recordings in 1893 on Edison cylinders. She is among the earliest female singers to be recorded. "She was born in Lancashire, England but moved with her family to Philadelphia, Pennsylvania at the age of six in 1879. She started performing on stage, including juvenile roles in the 1880s. "She sang in a contralto, learning songs by ear, and lacked the ability to read music or play an instrument. Her repertoire included ballads, ragtime, vaudeville, and comedy in a variety of dialects. During 1893–1894, she recorded for Edison Records on wax cylinders, making her among the earliest female singers to be recorded. She sang with Billy Murray, Billy Watkins, Cal Stewart, Len Spencer, the American Quartet, and with her 12-year-old daughter Sheilah. Touring was made difficult due to epilepsy. "In 1893 or 1894 she recorded some musical performances for the North American Phonograph Company, including "Sweet Marie" and "The Volunteer Organist". But the demise of this company interrupted her recording career and it was not until 1905 that she returned to recording, after a few years doing performances at such locations as Huber's 14th Street Museum in New York City. "Ada Jones recorded "The Yama Yama Man" in 1909 for the Victor Light Opera Company. The lyrics for verse two and three were changed from the original, verse two being more bawdy. It was the most popular song of her career, spending five weeks at number one." [1] There are several other photographs of Ada Jones in the Bain Collection of the Library of Congress that were first identified by [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] and [https://www.flickr.com/photos/60875295@N06]. Robert Lansing (1864-1928) was an American lawyer and Conservative Democratic politician who served as Legal Advisor to the State Department at the outbreak of World War I, and then as United States Secretary of State under President Woodrow Wilson from 1915 to 1920. "Before U.S. involvement in the war, Lansing vigorously advocated in favor of the principles of freedom of the seas and the rights of neutral nations. He later advocated U.S. participation in World War I, negotiated the Lansing–Ishii Agreement with Japan in 1917 and was a member of the American Commission to Negotiate Peace at Paris in 1919. "In 1919, Lansing became the nominal head of the US Commission to the Paris Peace Conference. Because he did not regard the League of Nations as essential to the peace treaty, Lansing began to fall out of favor with Wilson, for whom participation in the League of Nations was a primary goal. During Wilson's stroke and illness, Lansing called the cabinet together for consultations on several occasions. In addition, he was the first cabinet member to suggest that Vice President Thomas R. Marshall assume the powers of the presidency. Edith Wilson was displeased by Lansing's independence, and requested Lansing's resignation in 1920. "In 1890, Lansing married Eleanor Foster (1866-1934), the daughter of Secretary of State John W. Foster. Eleanor's older sister Edith was the mother of John Foster Dulles, who also became Secretary of State, Allen Welsh Dulles who served as Director of Central Intelligence, and Eleanor Lansing Dulles, an economist and high level policy analyst and advisor for the State Department. "New York State Senator Robert Lansing (1799–1878) was his grandfather; Chancellor John Lansing, Jr. and State Treasurer Abraham G. Lansing were his great-granduncles." [1]

Secretary of State Robert Lansing was in the news on the date [https://www.flickr.com/photos/53461717@N08/] deciphered, July 23, 1919. "After seven months in Paris as a member of the American Commission at the Peace Conference, Secretary of State Robert Lansing returned to this country on the Holland-America liner Rotterdam" on July 22, 1919. The Secretary was irked that the Internet Marconi Wireless on the Rotterdam had failed declaring he was completely out of touch with affairs. Secretary and Mrs. Lansing and other members of the delegation stayed overnight at the Hotel Biltmore before leaving for Washington on July 23, 1919.  [1]

Wilson Declares War on Germany One hundred years ago today, April 6, 1917, (at 1:18 PM ET) President Wilson declared war on Germany. A few days earlier Wilson made an address to a joint session of Congress asking that a resolution be passed, making the important distinction that a state of war with Germany already existed – and requesting Congress to declare it. (The particular photo uploaded last week shows a later Bain News Service publication date of 1919.)     Headlines • The New York Times • Page One • April 7, 1917                                                               – Read the full page (pdf) The President's proclamation to the American people announcing the existence of a state of war is as follows:                                      A PROCLAMATION. Whereas, the Congress of the United States, in the exercise of the constitutional authority vested in them, have resolved by joint resolution of the Senate and House of Representatives, bearing date this day, "that a state of war between the United States and the Imperial German Government which has been thrust upon the United States is hereby formally declared." – full text             "America Has Never Begun a Foreign War" – Editorial • The New York Times • April 8, 1917

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leland_B._Harrison "Leland B. Harrison (25 April 1883, in New York City – 6 June 1951, in Washington D.C.), was a United States diplomat. The son of W. Henry Harrison and Helen (Skidmore) Harrison." "In 1916 President Woodrow Wilson allowed Secretary of State Robert Lansing and Frank Polk quietly and informally to channel the flow of military and law enforcement material into the State Department's Bureau of Secret Intelligence (U-1), what is now known as the Diplomatic Security Service. The two men picked Leland Harrison 'to take charge of the collection and examination of all information of a secret nature coming into the Department from various sources and also to direct the work of the agents specially employed for that purpose.'"

Probably Edward Thomas Williams (October 17, 1854 - January 27, 1944), Chief of Division of Far Eastern Affairs, Department of State from 1914 to 1918, professor of Oriental Languages and Literature in the University of California from 1918 to 1927. This is the second of four ships of the United States Navy named USS George Washington in honor of George Washington. "USS George Washington (ID-3018), was a German ocean liner, launched in 1908. Great timing on the photographer's part.  Imagine the guys walking beside the car would have blocked the view of Wilson, and this was only a small window of time to get the shot.

It's not mentioned in the data provided here on or on the LOC site, but I believe this is Hoboken NJ - in front of City Hall on Washington St between Newark and 1st. Compare this photo from the Hoboken Historical Museum hoboken.pastperfectonline.com/archive/B2867763-2658-4483-... Also, the Serventi's (see sign at far left) owned the famous Hoboken "Clam Broth House" restaurant and other spots in town. The buildings in this picture on the corner of 1st would be torn down and replaced with an imposing bank within a few years - it's now a Walgreens.

This was after his return from the peace conference in Paris following WWI. New-York Tribune., July 08, 1919, page 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1919-07-08/ed-... has a large headline: "President Home To-day. City Ready to Greet Him." New-York Tribune., July 13, 1919, page 45 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1919-07-13/ed-... has pictures of his return from Paris on the USS George Washington to dock at Hoboken.
Scratched on the center top 7/8/19 (July 8, 1919

New-York Tribune., July 08, 1919, page 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1919-07-08/ed-... has a large headline: "President Home To-day. City Ready to Greet Him." The right-hand column describes the plans. The President and his wife would drive from Hoboken to New Tork City, where the celebrations would be on Fifth Avenue and at Carnegie Hall.

Testimony to the slow film speeds.  The shallow depth of field shows that the photographer was shooting with a wide aperture, and the blur of the walking guy's foot makes it look like about 1/30th or 1/60th of a second.
Nowadays, we'd shoot this at a smaller aperture & faster shutter speed.
Wilson returned from the peace conference in Paris on the en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_George_Washington arriving in Hoboken on July 8, 1919 (the date written on the negative).

In 1919, General Lionel Evelyn Oswald Charlton was air attaché to the British Embassy at Washington; Captain T. T. Craven was director of the United States Naval Air Service. Charlton was there to supervise the work of mooring the R-34 when she arrived. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1919-07-05/ed-... Homer Family This is a series of portraits of the family of composer Sidney Homer (1864-1953) and his wife contralto Louise Dilworth Homer née Beatty (1871-1947). Sidney Homer composed many of his songs with the voice of his famous wife in mind. Among his most famous songs are "A Banjo Song" (Weeden), "Requiem" (Stevenson), "Casey at the Bat" (Thayer), and "The House that Jack Built" ("Mother Goose.") Sidney was Louise's music theory teacher in Boston, MA. Louise Homer's European debut in 1898 was in Vichy, as Leonora in La Favorita, and in 1900 she made her American opera debut at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City singing Amneris in Verdi's Aida.  She sang at the Met for 19 consecutive seasons, often singing opposite such acclaimed singers as Enrico Caruso, Geraldine Farrar, and Ernestine Schumann-Heink.  Composer Samuel Barber was her nephew, and Louise performed several of his songs.  In 1923 and 1924 she was listed as one of the 12 greatest living women by the National League of Women Voters. They had six children, Louise Homer, Jr. (1896-1970) (Louise Homer Stires), son Sidney Homer, Jr. (1902-1983), twin daughters Anne Marie Homer (1907-1995) (Anne Homer Doerflinger) and Katharine Homer (1907-1997) ("Kay", Katharine Homer Fryer); and daughters Hester Makepeace Homer (b.1911) ("Miss Happy", Hester Homer Henry) and Helen Joy Homer (1915-1946) ("Joy", Joy Homer Doerflinger) There are currently 34 photographs of the Homer family in the Bain Collection on Flickr.  You can view them all here.   They were first identified by [https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog], [https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05], [https://www.flickr.com/photos/11418107@N02], [https://www.flickr.com/photos/70251312@N00], [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05], and [https://www.flickr.com/photos/richard_arthur_norton].

Homer Family This is a series of portraits of the family of composer Sidney Homer (1864-1953) and his wife contralto Louise Dilworth Homer née Beatty (1871-1947). Sidney Homer composed many of his songs with the voice of his famous wife in mind. Among his most famous songs are "A Banjo Song" (Weeden), "Requiem" (Stevenson), "Casey at the Bat" (Thayer), and "The House that Jack Built" ("Mother Goose.") Sidney was Louise's music theory teacher in Boston, MA.  After their marriage in 1895, they went to Europe for further voice coaching. Louise Homer's European debut in 1898 was in Vichy, as Leonora in La Favorita, and in 1900 she made her American opera debut at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City singing Amneris in Verdi's Aida.  She sang at the Met for 19 consecutive seasons, often singing opposite such acclaimed singers as Enrico Caruso, Geraldine Farrar, and Ernestine Schumann-Heink. She made many phonographic recordings with Victor Co.  Composer Samuel Barber was her nephew, and Louise performed several of his songs.  In 1923 and 1924 she was listed as one of the 12 greatest living women by the National League of Women Voters.[1] They had six children, Louise Homer, Jr. (1896-1970) (Louise Homer Stires), son Sidney Homer, Jr. (1902-1983), twin daughters Anne Marie Homer (1907-1995) (Anne Homer Doerflinger) and Katharine Homer (1907-1997) ("Kay", Katharine Homer Fryer); and daughters Hester Makepeace Homer (1911-1967) ("Miss Happy", Hester Homer Henry) and Helen Joy Homer (1915-1946) ("Joy", Joy Homer Doerflinger) There are currently 34 photographs of the Homer family in the Bain Collection on Flickr.  You can view them all here.   They were first identified by [https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog], [https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05], [https://www.flickr.com/photos/11418107@N02], [https://www.flickr.com/photos/70251312@N00], [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05], and [https://www.flickr.com/photos/richard_arthur_norton].

This is a series of portraits of the family of composer Sidney Homer (1864-1953) and his wife contralto Louise Dilworth Homer née Beatty (1871-1947). Louise Homer made her American opera debut at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City in 1900 singing Amneris in Verdi's Aida. She sang at the Met for 19 consecutive seasons, often singing opposite such acclaimed singers as Enrico Caruso, Geraldine Farrar, and Ernestine Schumann-Heink. Composer Samuel Barber was her nephew. She made many phonographic recordings with Victor Co.  Composer Samuel Barber was her nephew, and Louise performed several of his songs.  In 1923 and 1924 she was listed as one of the 12 greatest living women by the National League of Women Voters.[1] They had six children, Louise Homer, Jr. (1896-1970) (Louise Homer Stires), son Sidney Homer, Jr. (1902-1983), twin daughters Anne Marie Homer (1907-1995) (Anne Homer Doerflinger) and Katharine Homer (1907-1997) ("Kay", Katharine Homer Fryer); and daughters Hester Makepeace Homer (1911-1967) ("Miss Happy", Hester Homer Henry) and Helen Joy Homer (1915-1946) ("Joy", Joy Homer Doerflinger) There are currently 34 photographs of the Homer family in the Bain Collection on Flickr.  You can view them all here.   They were first identified by [https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog], [https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05], [https://www.flickr.com/photos/11418107@N02], [https://www.flickr.com/photos/70251312@N00], [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05], and [https://www.flickr.com/photos/richard_arthur_norton].

This is a series of portraits of the family of composer Sidney Homer (1864-1953) and his wife contralto Louise Dilworth Homer née Beatty (1871-1947). Homer composed many of his songs with the voice of his famous wife in mind. Among his most famous songs are "A Banjo Song" (Weeden), "Requiem" (Stevenson), "Casey at the Bat" (Thayer), and "The House that Jack Built" ("Mother Goose.") Louise Homer made her American opera debut at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City in 1900 singing Amneris in Verdi's Aida. She sang at the Met for 19 consecutive seasons, often singing opposite such acclaimed singers as Enrico Caruso, Geraldine Farrar, and Ernestine Schumann-Heink. Composer Samuel Barber was her nephew. In 1923 and 1924 she was listed as one of the 12 greatest living women by the National League of Women Voters. They had six children, including twin daughters Anne Homer and Kathryn Homer, son Sidney Homer, Jr. (economist and author), and daughter Louise Homer.  [1] [2] There are currently 33 photographs of the Homer family in the Bain Collection on Flickr. You can view them all here. Bert Williams, 1874-1922 "Egbert "Bert" Austin Williams was one of the greatest entertainers in America's history. Born in the Bahamas on November 12, 1874, he came to the United States permanently in 1885. "Williams met George Walker in San Francisco in 1893 and the two formed what became the most successful comedy team of their time. After appearing on Broadway in Victor Herbert's The Gold Bug (1896), Williams and Walker created pioneering vaudeville shows and full musical theater productions, including Senegambian Carnival (1897), The Policy Players (1899), The Sons of Ham (1900), their biggest hit, In Dahomey (1902)--which also played in London the following year, Abyssinia (1906), and Bandana Land (1907). "When Walker retired in 1908 due to illness, Williams starred in Mr. Load of Koal (1909)--the last black musical on Broadway for more than ten years. Unable to continue producing shows without Walker, Williams signed on with the Ziegfeld Follies in 1910--the only black performer in this famous review. He explained this controversial move saying, "... colored show business is at a low ebb just now ... it was far better to have joined a large white show than to have starred in a colored show, considering conditions." Williams stayed with the Follies through 1919, after which he appeared with Eddie Cantor in Broadway Brevities (1920) and Under the Bamboo Tree (1921-22). While on tour with the latter show, his failing health caught up with him and he contracted pneumonia. Williams died in New York City on March 4, 1922. "Williams was also one of the most prolific black performers on recordings, making around 80 recordings from 1901-22. Indeed, his first recording sessions with George Walker for the Victor Company in 1901 are considered the first recordings by black performers for a major recording company. Williams signed with Columbia in 1906 and the majority of his recordings were with that company, including what became his signature number, "Nobody," with words written by Alex Rogers." –From BIOGRAPHIES • Selected Works at the Library of Congress. This publicity still portrait was reportedly taken on January 01, 1920. There is a licensed companion photograph which appears to have been taken at the same time here. To look at some of Bert Williams' notated sheet music from the Ziegfeld Follies or to hear selected audio recordings, including his signature "Nobody", at the Library of Congress click here.

Marion Harris (1896 [or 1897] -1944) was an American popular singer who was most successful in the 1920s. She was the first widely known white singer to sing jazz and blues songs. [1] "Born Mary Ellen Harrison, in Vanderburgh County, Indiana, Marion Harris’ recording career began in 1916 with “I Ain’t Got Nobody Much” (“Much” was subsequently dropped from the song title) for Victor Records. "The songs that Marion Harris introduced or popularized include such standards as “After You’re Gone” (1918), “A Good Man Is Hard To Find” (1919), “Look For The Silver Lining” (1920), “I’m Nobody’s Baby” (1921), “Carolina In The Morning” (1922), “It Had To Be You” (1924), “Tea For Two” (1924), “I’ll See You In My Dreams” (1925) and “The Man I Love” (1927) just to name a few." [2]

Aviator Roy N. Francis next to the modified Martin MB-1 Bomber (Martin GMB-TA or "Martin GMT"; Air Service Serial No. A.S. 62949, Martin construction no. c/n 8) that he was to fly in an attempt of a one-stop (at North Platte, Nebraska) flight between New York and San Francisco in the summer of 1919. Unfortunately, on July 24, 1919, five days prior to the planned start of the flight, the aircraft was destroyed (see photo on Page 21 of cited journal below) when the hanger it was in at Hazelhurst Field (later Roosevelt Field), Mineola, was collapsed by a "cyclone, accompanyied by lightning" on that date. See: "U.S. Air Service," September 1919, "Coastal and Transcontinental Flights," Pages 21-22. For the details on the aircraft, see: Glenn L. Martin Aviation Museum - Martin Aircraft Specifications (1998)
ROY NEWELL FRANCIS 1886-1952 see also and www.earlyaviators.com/efrancis.htm

Col. R.S. Hartz, left the ground here [Washington, DC] at 10 A.M. on the first leg of a flight of nearly 8,000 miles around the rim of the country." [2]

Presumably en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallace_Notestein The bio with his papers, held by Yale University: Wallace Notestein (December 16, 1578-1969) was born in Wooster, Ohio; son of Jonas O, and Margaret (Wallace) Notestein. He married Ada Louise Comstock, June 14, 1943. He received his B. A. from Wooster in 1900 and his Ph. D. from Yale in 1908. .... Notestein was assistant professor of history, University of Kansas, 1905-1907; instructor of history, University of Minnesota, 1908; assistant professor, 1910, associate professor, 1914, professor, 1917-1920; professor of English History, Cornell, 1920-1928; Sterling Professor English History, Yale, 1928-1947, emeritus, 1947-; Eastman Professor Oxford University, 1949-1950; fellow Balliol College, 1949-1950; Research Assistant, Committee on Public Information, 1917; attached to State Department, 1918, American Commission to Negotiate Peace, Paris, 1919;

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Homer_Haskins "Charles Homer Haskins (December 21, 1870 – May 14, 1937) was an American historian of the Middle Ages, and advisor to U.S. President Woodrow Wilson. " "Haskins became politically involved enough to become a close advisor of U.S. President Woodrow Wilson, whom he had met at Johns Hopkins. When Wilson attended the Paris Peace Conference of 1919 where the Treaty of Versailles was drawn up, he brought only three advisors including Haskins, who served as chief of the Western European division of the American commission."
See www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/16475697238/

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Dmowski "Roman Stanisław Dmowski [ˈrɔman staˈɲiswaf ˈdmɔfski] (9 August 1864 – 2 January 1939) was a Polish politician, statesman, and co-founder and chief ideologue of the right-wing National Democracy ("ND": in Polish, "Endecja") political movement" "As a Polish delegate at the Paris Peace Conference and a signatory of the Versailles Treaty, Dmowski exerted a substantial influence on the Treaty's favorable decisions regarding Poland. On 29 January 1919, Dmowski met with the Allies' Supreme War Council for the first time; his five-hour presentation there, delivered in English and French, was described as brilliant"

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Hawker "After the war, together with navigator Kenneth Mackenzie Grieve, he attempted to win the Daily Mail £10,000 prize for the first flight across the Atlantic in "72 consecutive hours". On 18 May 1919, they set off from Mount Pearl, Newfoundland, in the Sopwith Atlantic biplane. After fourteen and a half hours of flight, the engine overheated and they were forced to change course to intercept the shipping lanes, where they were able to locate a passing freighter, the Danish Mary. The Mary did not have a functioning radio, so that it was not until six days later, when the steamer reached Butt of Lewis, Scotland, that word was received that they were safe. Hawker and Grieve were awarded a consolation prize of £5,000 by the Daily Mail." The picture in London may have been after this series of events.

See also www.motorsportmagazine.com/archive/article/october-1998/4... which includes the sentence, "So great were the crowds when the heroes were later due at the Royal Aero Club, that Hawker had to abandon the 40/50 Rolls-Royce tourer for a police horse. "

This is daredevil John “Jammie” Reynolds (1888-1926).  The son of a steeplejack in West Philadelphia, PA, "Reynolds began performing at the age six in Buffalo, balancing on one foot from a flagpole 140 feet in the air." [1] [2]  Kristi Finefield of the Library of Congress put together an awesome collection of photographs and information about Jammie Reynolds in her recent blog post, Double Take: Detecting a Daredevil  (January 27, 2017). We also get to take a look over Kristi's shoulder as she researches a photo starting with just a fragment of information!
"While working on a reference question about a building on 9th Street N.W. in Washington, D.C. and browsing through older photos of that street in the Prints and Photographs Online Catalog, one dramatic photo made me do a double take. What on Earth is going on at the top of this building?"

According to the caption of a similar photo in The evening world., June 14, 1919, Final Edition, Image 2, this photo was taken on the twenty-fifth story of the Herald Sqare Building chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1919-06-14/ed-...

Most sources refer to him as Jack Reynolds. "All were eager to see “Daredevil Jack – the “Human Fly” – cheat death on this Saturday night in July, 1922. Jack Reynolds was 31 years old and he’d been doing this type of stunt for a long time. An acrobat and juggler, the Philadelphia daredevil was known by many names – Daredevil Johnny, the Climbing Wonder, and The Lizard, to name a few." thesarniajournal.ca/when-the-human-fly-thrilled-a-downtow... See also photos in - Evening public ledger., February 04, 1915, Sports Final, Image 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045211/1915-02-04/ed-... - Evening public ledger., February 05, 1915, Sports Final, Image 16 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045211/1915-02-05/ed-... - The Washington times., September 06, 1917, FINAL EDITION, Page 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1917-09-06/ed-... - The West Virginian., May 19, 1922, Image 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86072054/1922-05-19/ed-...

From the Wikipedia article, "Raymonde de Laroche (22 August 1882 – 18 July 1919), born Elise Raymonde Deroche, was a French pilot and the first woman in the world to receive an aeroplane pilot's licence."
"On 18 July 1919 de Laroche, who was a talented engineer, went to the airfield at Le Crotoy as part of her plan to become the first professional woman test pilot. She co-piloted an experimental aircraft (whether she flew this plane or was a passenger at the time is not known); on its landing approach the aeroplane went into a dive and crashed, killing both de Laroche and the co-pilot."

Sophie Braslau (1892-1935) was a contralto prominent in United States opera, starting with her debut in New York City's Metropolitan Opera in 1913 when she was just 21 years of age. [1] In her obituary The New York Times wrote, "The singer considered as her greatest triumph an experience during a rehearsal for a concert at Richmond, Va., where she had been sent to substitute for Mme. Louise Homer. After an introduction to the musicians in the empty auditorium, she sang an aria for rehearsal."
"I finished and there came a dead silence," she recalled later, "quickly followed by the strangest sound I had ever heard.  The musicians tapped their music stands with their bows or clapped their hands." In a few seconds it seemed as if pandemonium had let loose, and how happy I was! It was really the finest moment of my life. My mother was there, and it seemed to me that this was her triumph, for the evening concert was a great success and this was the first big joy she had experienced after her many years of devoted supervision."
(Many photographs of Mme. Homer can be seen in the LOC Bain Collection here.) There are currently nine photographs of Sophie Braslau in the LOC Bain Collection from c.1910-1915 here.)
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sophie_Braslau

"Les installations et les chiffres cités disent tout le gigantisme du camp. On sait que 500,000 soldats sont passés par le camp de Noyers-Saint-Aignan et qu’en 1918, 180,000 d’entre eux ont été envoyés vers 500 destinations différentes après leur entraînement ou les soins reçus. En 1919, le camp est surchargé de soldats dans l’attente du ré-embarquement vers les états-unis. 30,000 logent à noyers dans des tentes, baraquements, granges, greniers. Noyers a, à l’époque, moins de 2000 habitants." So, in 1919, this was a camp used for U.S. soldiers waiting for transport back to the U.S.

Col. Ruby D. Garrett (1882-1968) "INTRODUCTION The Dwight Ruby [sic] Garrett collection contains papers and photographs of Garrett, a Kansas City, MO, lawyer. Garrett commanded the 117th Field Signal Battalion, 42nd (Rainbow) Division, U.S. Army, American Expeditionary Force. The collection concentrates on his World War I and postwar veterans activities. The clipping scrapbook is on microfilm. BIOGRAPHICAL SKETCH Ruby Dwight Garrett, the son of Mary Ellen (Phillips) and the Reverend John Newton Garrett, was born 22 July 1882, in Alamance County, North Carolina. Garrett attended Yadkin College, then served in the U.S. Army from 1902 to 1905. In 1908 Garrett received his law degree from Kansas City University and was admitted to the Missouri bar. He was a practicing attorney in Kansas City, serving as assistant prosecuting attorney, 1910-1911. Garrett served for ten years as general counsel for the Kansas City Chamber of Commerce and was a member-at-large of the city council, 1931-1940. Concurrent with his law practice, Garrett was a captain in the Missouri National Guard Signal Troops, 1909-1916, with service on the Mexican border. In 1917 he returned to regular Army service with the 42nd (Rainbow) Division, American Expeditionary Force, as chief signal officer. Garrett attained the rank of colonel and was awarded the Purple Heart and the French Croix de Guerre with Palm. He returned to civilian life in 1919 after service across Europe and with the Army of Occupation in Germany. Garrett was an organizer, incorporator, and member of the American Legion. He was also a member of the United States Signal Corps Association, the Reserve Officers Association, the Disabled American Veterans, the Veterans of Foreign Wars, and the Rainbow Division Veterans Association of Missouri. In 1959 Garrett received the Army Exceptional Civilian Service Award. Garrett was an active member of several Kansas City social clubs and civic organizations. He was a Mason, a Democrat, and a Unitarian. In 1909 Ruby D. Garrett married Alma Marie Ahlfeldt ( -1971). They were the parents of one son, Ruby D., Jr., and two daughters, Rachel (Mrs. C. Weber, Jr.) and Bonnie. Ruby D. Garrett died in 1968. " shsmo.org/manuscripts/columbia/2558.pdf

C-5 was a hydrogen inflated C class blimp operated by the U.S. Navy in 1918 and 1919. It was one of ten C class non-rigid airships built by Goodyear and Goodrich primarily for training and patrol duty for the navy during World War I. History The C-5's engines were built by Hispano-Suiza, and its control car was built by Curtiss Aeroplane and Motor Company. In early May 1919, the C-5 made a pioneering flight from its home base at Cape May, New Jersey to Montauk Point, New York and St. John's, Newfoundland, becoming the first airship to reach that city and in the process sending the first radio voice transmission from Newfoundland. The C-5's goal was to fly across the Atlantic, paralleling the route used by the U.S. seaplane NC-4. Previous attempts to cross the Atlantic Ocean in a balloon were unsuccessful. The most famous of these attempts was that of the dirigible America in October 1910. On 14 May 1919, the C-5 departed Montauk Point in clear weather. It made good time, but encountered heavy fog and thunderstorms near Saint Pierre Island, Canada and became lost for several hours. It eventually regained its way, but the extended trip caused the crew to exhaust its food supply and wind and rain continuously buffeted the blimp. The C-5 again became lost, this time over Newfoundland itself, when its radio navigation equipment malfunctioned. The C-5's crew used its voice radio to contact the U.S. Navy cruiser Chicago, which was in St. John's, and the radio signal was used to guide the C-5 to the tracks of the Colonial Railroad, which it followed to St. John's and a safe landing at 11 a.m. on 15 May. The commander of the blimp, Lieutenant Commander Coll, said it was the roughest trip he had ever experienced. Most of the crew left to eat lunch and sleep, while the few remaining men began to service the blimp's engines. In the meantime, a storm rolled in and additional cables were tied over the blimp in order to secure it and crewmen from the Chicago were brought in to help. The wind intensified from 30 miles per hour (48 km/h) to 40 miles per hour (64 km/h) with higher gusts, and the blimp began to break free from its additional cables. The engines couldn't be restarted because they were under maintenance, so Lieutenant Charles Little attempted to pull the emergency cord to open the gasbag and deflate it. The cord broke, and the C-5 began to lift off, tearing a few remaining cables that injured two crewmen as they sprang loose. Little jumped from the rising blimp, injuring his ankle, and the C-5 was blown eastward, over the Atlantic Ocean. The destroyer USS Edwards was dispatched to retrieve the blimp, which continued to drift. Later news reports that the C-5 crashed into the Atlantic and was found by a passing British ship were false.There were also reports that the C-5 may have been sighted over Ireland, but these were never substantiated. The C-5 was never seen again. On the same day the C-5 broke loose from its moorings, the British government announced plans to send the airship R-34 on a transatlantic flight to Cape May, the C-5's home base. That airship successfully crossed the Atlantic, becoming the first aircraft to navigate that body of water from east to west nonstop. Specifications (typical C class blimp) General characteristics Crew: Four Length: 196 ft 0 in (59.76 m) Diameter: 42 ft 0 in (12.80 m) Height: 54 ft 0 in (16.46 m) Volume: 181,000 ft3 (5,125 m3) Useful lift: 4,050 lb (1,837 kg) Powerplant: 2 × Hispano-Suiza, 150 hp (112 kW) each Performance Maximum speed: 60 mph (97 km/h) Cruise speed: 40 mph (64 km/h) Range: 1,440 miles (2,320 km) Endurance: 31 hours 30 min Service ceiling: 8,600 ft (2,620 m) Armament 1 × .303 Lewis gun 4 × 270 lb (122 kg) bombs en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C-5_%28blimp%29

The hulk of USS Baltimore was recently discovered at about 600 meters (1,970 feet) depth, upright and intact on the flat sandy bottom of the Musicians Seamounts, northwest of Oahu. It was there where she was towed out to sea and scuttled on September 22, 1944, after a long and varied career with the US Navy. Baltimore was even present at Pearl Harbor, serving as a receiving ship, during the surprise attack by the Imperial Japanese Navy (IJN) on December 7, 1941. Below is a link to high-definition video of her hulk taken by one of NOAAS Okeanos Explorer's (R 337) remotely operated vehicles (ROV), on September 29, 2017. She is in relatively good shape considering her age and the 70-plus years spent on the ocean floor. Note also the footage of her distinctive stern opening (added to the ship when she was fitted for mine-laying), that is also apparent in this series of Bain photos of the NC flying boats' stopover in Nova Scotia. oceanexplorer.noaa.gov/okeanos/explorations/ex1708/dailyu...

He was a Distinguished Graduate, School of the Line, 1921. Married: Jessie Hamilton, November 18, 1908 and married a decond time to Mary Kelly Mayer, Nov 1, 1958. Commissioned a Second Lieutenant, Cavalry, 1901 and was promoted the through grades to Brigadier General, 1936, Major General 1938. He served in the Philippines 1903-05 and 1909-11. He participated in Aisne-Marne, Oise Aisne Meuse Argonne offensives, World War One with Army of Occupation, Germany, 1918-19. Executive Officer, War Plans Division, General Staff, 1920. Instructor, the Cavalry School, 1926-30. Instructor, Command and General Staff School, 1926-30. Instructor, Army War College, 1931-35. Commanding General, 2nd Cavalry Brigade, 1936-38. Assistant Chief of Staff, Operations and Training Division, War Department General Staff, 1938-39. Retired 1939. Awarded: Distinguished Service Medal, Croix de Guerre with Palm, Officer of Legion of Honor (France). Lutheran. Mason. Home: Washington, DC Died: July 4, 1970 and was buried in Section 30 of Arlington National Cemetery. www.arlingtoncemetery.net/rmbeck.htm and "Birth: May 9, 1879 Death: Jul. 4, 1970 Note: AR United States Army Burial: Arlington National Cemetery Arlington Arlington County Virginia, USA Plot: Sec: 30, Site: 887-1" www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=beck&a...;

Man on right may be Capt. Daniel D. Thomson. His Silver Star citation "Captain Thomson distinguished himself by gallantry in action while serving as Aide-de-Camp to the Commanding General, 32d Division, American Expeditionary Forces, in action southwest of Romagne, France, 14 October 1918, in securing valuable information under enemy fire." From the 32d division site, a notation indicating his name was sometimes spelled Thompson: "Thomson, Daniel Duke (Thompson) Captain, U.S. Army Headquarters, 32D ‘Red Arrow’ Division, A.E.F. Date of Action: 14 October 1918 Citation: “By direction of the President, under the provisions of the act of Congress approved July 9, 1918 (Bul. No. 43, W.D., 1918), Captain Daniel D. Thomson, United States Army, is cited by the Commanding General, American Expeditionary Forces, for gallantry in action and a silver star may be placed upon the ribbon of the Victory Medals awarded him. Captain Thomson distinguished himself by gallantry in action while serving as Aide-de-Camp to the Commanding General, 32d Division, American Expeditionary Forces, in action southwest of Romagne, France, 14 October 1918, in securing valuable information under enemy fire.” General Orders: GHQ, American Expeditionary Forces, Citation Orders No. 8 (March 1, 1920) Born: 28 October 1893 at Kentucky Hometown: Louisville, Kentucky Death: 21 April 1970 at California Interred: Victor Valley Memorial Park, Victorville, California He attended Central U. of Ky., freshman ca. '13; Capt. in Officers' Reserve Corps; assigned Aide-de-Camp to Maj. Gen. William G. Haan, 32D Div.; rode to France on USS George Washington; earned Silver Star Citation for his actions 14 Oct. '18 near Romagne; also earned Div. Citation, which was likely basis for Silver Star Citation; also earned Croix de Guerre; brother Capt. Robert R. also served; Maj. in Officers' Reserve Corps and resided at 700 W. Main St., Louisville, KY, ca. '20; married Constance Eugenia Smith on 18 May '20, father of at least 1; also served during WWII; attained rank of Lt. Col.; president of Axton-Fisher Tobacco Co." www.32nd-division.org/history/ww1/ss-ww1/SS-32ww1.html

New-York tribune., April 13, 1919, Page 7, column 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1919-04-13/ed-... describes "Victory Way." It was on Park Avenue between 45th and 50th Streets. The speaker's stand was near 48th Street. The backdrop is also described: 'A frieze of mural paintings, 160 feet long and 10 feet high, behind a speakers' stand near Forty-eighth Street, will present the concept of victory through the medium of seven paintings. In the centre panel will be "Victory,"' by Arthur Crisp, vice-president of the Architectural League of America. Three others will appear at each side. Each will depict the contribution of a continent to the combined attainment. J. M. Hewlett, painter and sculptor, has done "Australia and New Zealand"; Charles S. Chapman, "South America"; Frederick J. Waugh, "North America"; W. T. Benda, "Europe"; Arthur S. Covey, "Africa," and Edith M. Magonigle, "Asia."' Photos of the murals and a picture of Victory Way can be seen in the American Magazine of Art, Volume 10, page 475, October 1919. books.google.com/books?id=11HrAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA475&l...

The second USS Tennessee (ACR-10), also referred to as "Armored Cruiser No. 10", and later renamed Memphis, was a United States Navy armored cruiser, the lead ship of her class.

She was laid down by the Cramp Shipbuilding Company of Philadelphia on 20 June 1903,[1] launched on 3 December 1904, sponsored by Ms. Annie K. Frazier (daughter of Governor James B. Frazier of Tennessee and later the foundress of the Society of Sponsors of the United States Navy), and commissioned at the Philadelphia Navy Yard on 17 July 1906, Captain Albert Gleaves Berry in command.[2]
This is the battleship USS Tennessee (BB-43), launched on April 30, 1919, see also the nearby photo: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/32646386646/in/...
Thanks for the information about the USS Tennessee (BB-43). We will add more details to the description.

Frazier of Tennessee and later the foundress of the Society of Sponsors of the United States Navy), and commissioned at the Philadelphia Navy Yard on 17 July 1906, Captain Albert Gleaves Berry in command.[2]
This is the battleship USS Tennessee (BB-43), launched on April 30, 1919, see also the nearby photo: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/32646386646/in/...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Henry_Towers "John Henry Towers (January 30, 1885 – April 30, 1955) was a United States Navy admiral and pioneer naval aviator. He made important contributions to the technical and organizational development of naval aviation from its very beginnings, eventually serving as Chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics (1939–1942). He commanded carrier task forces during World War II, and retired in December 1947. " "In 1919, then-Commander Towers proposed, planned and led the first air crossing of the Atlantic. Planning for the mission actually began during the early years of World War I, when Allied shipping was threatened by submarine warfare, but could not be accomplished prior to the war's end. The flying expedition began on 8 May 1919 when three Curtiss NC Flying Boats, designated NC-1, NC-3 and NC-4, left Naval Air Station Rockaway, New York, The aircraft made intermediate stops in Chatham, Massachusetts and Halifax, Nova Scotia before reaching Trepassey, Newfoundland on 15 May 1919. On 16 May they left for the longest leg of their journey, to the Azores. NC-1 and the NC-3 were both forced to land in heavy seas due to dense fog, and neither could take off again. NC-1 subsequently began taking on water and the crew was rescued by the Greek freighter Ionia The crew of the NC-3, including Towers, managed to keep the NC-3 afloat for 52 hours, water taxiing the craft over 200 miles to Punta Delgada on Sao Miguel Island. NC-4 went on to complete the transatlantic crossing, arriving at Lisbon on 27 May. For his leadership in the operation, Towers was awarded the Navy Cross. Ten years later, Towers and the flight crew of NC-4 were awarded Congressional Gold Medals."

Howard was a special mechanic on NC-4. Christensen was on NC-1. Rhodes was on NC-3.

Chief Mechanic's Mate Edward H. Howard would suffer the misfortune of losing his left hand to a whirling propeller on the eve of the transatlantic expedition while working on an engine. He would be replaced on NC-4's crew by Eugene T. "Smokey" Rhoads (no relation to Braxton Rhodes).
