Willard Townshend Chevalier (1886-1961) laurel.lso.missouri.edu:2083/iii/encore/search/C__SCheval... From digital.lafayette.edu/collections/newspaper/19360317/pdf: www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05/32567206055/

"... Colonel Willard Chevalier, Vice-President of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Co., of New York City. ... graduated from the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute in 1910 with the degree of Civil Engineer. As an Engineer, he worked on the New York subways and the New York State Barge Canal and other projects both on design and construction. From May, 1917, to May, 1919, he served progressively as Captain, Major and Lieutenant-Colonel with the 11th United States Field Engineers Corps on field service in France. During more than half of this time, he was brigaded with the B.E.F. Early in 1922, he entered the publishing field as Associate Editor of Engineering News-Record. Later, he became its publisher. In 1926, he launched a new venture in the publishing field, a pictorial construction review Construction Methods. In 1934, he was elected Vice-President and Director of the Company with which he is now associated and assumed charge of their mining as well as the construction publications. He also writes a column each week for another of the Company's well-known journals Business Week of which he is now publisher." speeches.empireclub.org/60719/data

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maria_Laach_Abbey Catalogue of official A.E.F. photographs, 1919: "48522 [1168N91. Front view of the church of Benedictine Abbey of Laach, founded in 1093 by Count Palatine Henry, once one of the wealthiest and most celebrated in Germany. The abbey was suppressed by the French in 1802 and from 1863 to 1873 it was in the hands of the Jesuits who established a school here for pupils of the order. In 1893 it was restored to the Benedictines. The church, completed in 1156, with dome, transepts, two choirs, five towers, and crypt, is a noble example of Romanesque style, being most impressive externally. The upper parts of the towers and the porch in front of the west facade, restored in 1859, belong to the close of the twelfth century. Laacher See, Rhine Province, Germany. January 2, 1919." archive.org/stream/cu31924027944598#page/n511/mode/2up/

"Rainbow Division The 42nd came to be known as the "Rainbow Division". When the United States declared war on Germany in 1917, it federalized National Guard divisions to quickly build up an Army. In addition, Douglas MacArthur, then a major, suggested to William A. Mann, the head of the Militia Bureau, that he form another division from the non-divisional units of several states. Secretary of War Newton D. Baker approved the proposal, and recalled Douglas MacArthur saying that such an organization would "stretch over the whole country like a rainbow." The division was created using units from 26 states and the District of Columbia. The name stuck, and MacArthur was promoted to colonel as the division chief of staff. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/42nd_Infantry_Division_(United_States)

A 14-inch/50-caliber gun and Mark I Army Railway Mount built by Baldwin Locomotive Works. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/14%22/50_caliber_railway_gun See: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/32432654791/

Apparently one of three railway guns (each mounting a 14-in/50" caliber naval gun) built by Baldwin Locomotive Works for the US Army (given the "U.S.A." markings; US Navy railway guns were marked "U.S.N" or "U.S. Navy") during the First World War. These were identical to the US Navy's Mark I railway guns. However, unlike the Navy's railway guns, the US Army's railway guns did not see combat. They were completed in September 1918 and not shipped to Europe prior to the Armistice. See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/14%22/50_caliber_railway_gun

"BAKER, CERES United States Born 24 August 1904 in Newark, New Jersey Died 27 February 1982 in Arlington, Texas Married Raymond Palmer Sackett before August 1924-later divorced Active 1918-1925. Ceres competed in adult events from the young age of 13. A member of the Orange Tennis Club, her game was compared to the male star Vinnie Richards. An article from 1919, when she was only 15, notes she was already better than most women at net and tactics, lacking only "severity" on her ground strokes, in which she favored chops and slices. In 1920 Ceres made the doubles final with Eleanor "Teach" Tennant, falling to Goss/Zinderstein 13-11 4-6 6-3. Married in the mid 1920s, the couple lived in Orange at least up to the 1930, with a son named Ray P born in 1928. They later moved to Texas. Her death certificate indicates she was divorced, but was signed by her ex-husband." www.tennisforum.com/58132594-post3379.html

The sun., May 30, 1919, Page 12, col. 5 reported that she was defeated in the final round of the Metropolitan tennis championship by Helen Rice. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1919-05-30/ed-...

Inspector Owen Eagan of the Department of Combustibles, New York Fire Department . Looks like he's inspecting some bombs, which was his job. This negative is dated March 8, 1920, around the time of his death on March 2 of that year, but that is obviously just noting use of the negative at that time. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1920-03-03/ed-... "OWEN EAGAN The career of the late Owen Eagan was an evidence of the truth of the saying that to fear a danger is to invite it For twenty four years Mr Eagan was the undaunted expert bomb analyzer and infernal machine destroyer for New York City's police force In that time he diagnosed and picked apart more than seven thousand suspicious packages from the crudest bomb made by a Black I lander on the East Side to the most elaborate product of the skill of able metal workers and explosive manipulators And yet although he was injured several times Mr Eagan escaped the pessimistic predictions of life insurance companies to die the other day of acute indigestion As the New York Sun points out he respected bombs but did not fear them." The Outlook, March 17, 1920. books.google.com/books?id=C4mrHT2tZ2wC&pg=PA456&l... According to this account in Popular Science from 1932, Eagan lost "the fingers of his right hand" in an explosion in March, 1912. books.google.com/books?id=SSgDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA110&d... He had been in the newspapers, including a picture, in connection with a terrorist bombing on E. 61st Street in New York in June, 1919. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1919-06-04/ed-...

"Vallois, Robert Captain of Air Service, French Army Observer, 16th Pursuit Group, French Air Service Date of Action: September 12, 1918 Citation: The Distinguished Service Cross is presented to Robert Vallois, Captain of Air Service, French Army, for extraordinary heroism in action near Thiaucourt, France. Captain Vallois volunteered to fly with Major Lewis H. Brereton on an important reconnaissance mission. On account of poor visibility they were forced to fly at a very low altitude and were continually harassed by antiaircraft fire. Four enemy monoplanes (type Fokker) attacked them, and during the combat which followed Captain Vallois' gun jammed. After withdrawing for the purpose of clearing the jam they again returned to the fight, and, despite the fact that he had been painfully wounded in the face, Captain Vallois succeeded in dispersing three of the adversaries and fought off the other while his pilot made a landing. General Orders No. 46, W.D., 1919 Resident of France" www.homeofheroes.com/valor/books/foreign/02_FOREIGN-DSCww...

"Ira Beaman Joralemon (1884 – 1975) was an American mining engineer, economic geologist, and mining company executive, who specialized in exploration and mining of copper ore deposits. Over a career spanning more than six decades, Joralemon was involved in the discovery and development of numerous major copper and gold deposits, many of which went on to become operational mines. In addition to his professional career within the minerals industry, he was also a popular science author and historian of the mining industry. [...] His work with the C&A Company was interrupted by World War I, during which Joralemon served with the United States Army Air Service between 1917 and 1919. For part of this time Major Joralemon was a member of General Billy Mitchell's staff, and was commended by Mitchell for his "wonderful work" during preparations for the Battle of Saint-Mihiel.[5] For his service to France the French government awarded him the distinction of Chevalier of the Legion d'Honneur in 1918." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ira_Joralemon

An interesting backstory on the photographer, Harry Whittier Frees (1879-1953): "Frees created images for magazines, calendars, books and postcards for more than a half century from 1902 to 1953. ... "The work was challenging, time-consuming and nerve-wracking. It caused Frees so much anxiety that he photographed his furry subjects for only three months a year. To make the situation even more difficult for Frees, only about 30 [sheet film] negatives out of every 100 could be used. Consequently, he needed the remainder of the year to recuperate from exhaustion and formulate new ideas." – Pennsylvania Heritage Magazine

James Alexander Ferguson (February 16, 1897 – April 26, 1976) was a pitcher in Major League Baseball who played for five different teams between 1918 and 1929. Listed at 6 ft 0 in (1.83 m), 180 lb., Ferguson batted and threw right-handed. He was born in Montclair, New Jersey and died in Sepulveda, California, at age 79.
Professional career[edit]
Ferguson was one of the first forkball specialists in major league history. He entered the majors in 1918 with the New York Yankees, playing for them two years (1918, 1921) before joining the Boston Red Sox (1922–1925), Washington Senators (1925–1926), again the Yankees (1925), and with the Philadelphia Phillies (1927–1929) and Brooklyn Robins (1925). He enjoyed his highest win season in 1924 with the seventh-place Red Sox, when he won 14 games while losing an American League-high 17. In 1925 he divided his playing time with Boston, New York and Washington, ending with a 5–1 mark and a 3.25 ERA in seven games for the Senators AL champion team. During the World Series, he pitched well against the Pittsburgh Pirates, going 1–1 with a 3.21 ERA in two starts.
In a 10-season career, Ferguson posted a 61–85 record with 397 strikeouts and a 4.89 ERA in 257 appearances, including 166 starts, 62 complete games, two shutouts, 10 saves, and 1241⅔ innings of work.
In 1926 Ferguson set a major league record for the highest ERA during a regular season by a pitcher who started a postseason game the same year. Ferguson collected a combined 6.18 ERA while pitching with the Red Sox, Yankees and Senators. The mark was broken in 2006 by Óliver Pérez of the New York Mets, who posted a 6.55 ERA during the regular season before starting Game 4 of the NL Championship Series.

""The 332nd Infantry Regiment was an infantry regiment of the United States Army, active during World War I. It was part of the 83rd Infantry Division and served on the Italian front during the war, taking part in the Battle of Vittorio Veneto. It was disbanded in May 1919. [...] n February 1919 the 332nd Infantry Regiment received orders to return to the United States. As the regiment's three battalions had been spread out around the theatre it was not until 29 March 1919 that the regiment embarked upon the SS Duca d'Aosta. This is probably from what is now known in English as Sonchon or Sonch’on, North Korea, a town and county in the far northwest of the country. It was also spelled Sen Sen, Syen Shun, Syen Chun and a few other variations in early 20th century publications. A 1917 report on Protestant missionary activity describes it: "Syen Chun is our northernmost Station in Korea situated 100 miles northwest of Pyeng Yang in the thickly populated country which borders on the Yellow Sea." books.google.com/books?id=zYJEAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA5-PA211&a... map: mapcarta.com/16085174 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonchon_County see also: books.google.com/books?id=h2gwAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA196&d... books.google.com/books?id=Xw7PAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA129&l...

Sacha Votichenko, musician. His NYT obituary: "SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Oct. 30 —Sacha Votichenko, Russianborn musician who until recently had taught in New York, died here on Oct. 22. He was 83 years old. Mr. Votichenko performed in concert on the royal tympanon, a keyless instrument, predecessor of the harpsichord, struck with padded hammers, much like the dulcimer and the more familiar Hungarian czymbalorn. His tympanon, which was believed to be the only one of its kind in the world, was made in 1705 by Pantaloon Hebenstreit, from whom he was descended. A son, Terry, and three grandsons survive." www.nytimes.com/1971/10/31/archives/sacha-votichenko-83-d... LOC has some Arnold Genthe portraits of Votichenko and his family from 1916 and 1918. www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=votichenko

The 'royal tympanon' was probably a pantalon (or pantaleon), "a large variation on the hammered dulcimer, invented by Pantaleon Hebenstreit in the early 18th century and briefly popular in France and Germany." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pantalon

"Hon. Rachel Cecily Douglas-Scott-Montagu F, #68513, b. circa 1870, d. 12 April 1962 Last Edited=26 Dec 2014 Consanguinity Index=0.07% Hon. Rachel Cecily Douglas-Scott-Montagu was born circa 1870. She was the daughter of Henry John Montagu Douglas-Scott-Montagu, 1st Baron Montagu of Beaulieu and Hon. Cecily Susan Stuart-Wortley-Mackenzie.1,2 She married Henry William Forster, 1st and last Baron Forster, son of Major John Forster and Emily Jane Case, on 3 June 1890.3 She died on 12 April 1962.2 Her married name became Forster. As a result of her marriage, Hon. Rachel Cecily Douglas-Scott-Montagu was styled as Baroness Forster on 12 December 1919. She was invested as a Dame Grand Cross, Order of the British Empire (G.B.E.) in 1926.3 She was invested as a Dame of Grace, Order of St. John of Jerusalem (D.G.St.J.)3" www.thepeerage.com/p6852.htm Lord Forster married the Honourable Rachel Cecily Douglas-Scott-Montagu, daughter of the 1st Baron Montagu of Beaulieu, in 1890. After Forster's return from Australia they settled near Southampton, and lived quietly until Forster's death in 1936. Lady Forster was invested as a Dame Grand Cross of the Order of the British Empire (GBE) in 1926. She was also invested as a Dame of Grace of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Forster,_1st_Baron_Forster "Sir Henry William Forster (1866-1936), governor-general, was born on 31 January 1866 at Southend Hall, Kent, England, son of Major John Forster, late 6th Dragoon Guards, and his wife Emily Jane, née Case. Educated at Eton and New College, Oxford (B.A., 1889), he excelled at tennis and fencing, played cricket for Eton, Oxford and Kent, captained Hampshire, and represented the Gentleman against Players. Over six feet (183 cm) tall, he was of the spare, typical sportsman's build. On 3 June 1890 he married Rachel Cecily, daughter of the first Lord Montagu of Beaulieu. A Unionist, in 1892-1918 Forster represented Sevenoaks and in 1918-19 Bromley in the House of Commons. He was a junior lord of the Treasury in 1902-05, Conservative whip 1902-11 and financial secretary to the War Office 1915-19. Appointed privy councillor in 1917, next year he became president of the Marylebone Cricket Club and in 1919 he was created Baron Forster of Lepe." adb.anu.edu.au/biography/forster-sir-henry-william-6213

New York, New York. Italian-American policeman chatting with customers in a grocery store on Mulberry Street Marjory Collins (1912-1985), photographer • January, 1943

Happy New Year!   This is Bartolomeo Dicostanzo with his wife Jennie Dicostanzo sharing a toast to the New Year 1943 from behind the bar at their restaurant, Marconi's at 114-116 Mulberry Street in the heart of the "Little Italy" section of New York City. The DiCostanzo family consisted of at least 7 children, Frank, Luca, Pasquale, Anna, Mary (age 30 at the time of this photo), Tacy, and Rosie. [ 1 ]   No doubt their extended family numbered into high double digits.   They celebrated an annual tradition of a New Year's Eve dinner at their restaurant. There are several other photographs of the dinner, as well as the chef, in the same series photographed by Marjory Collins in the FSA/OWI Collection of The Library of Congress that haven't yet made their way to the flickr stream. Here's a photo of two of the daughters that night, along with a photo showing the DiCostanzo family enjoying their annual New Year's Eve Dinner.
Two of the Di Costanzo girls at their New Year's family party. Marjory Collins (1912-1985), photographer • December 31 1942
The Di Costanzo family, owners of a restaurant on Mulberry Street, hold their annual family dinner in the restaurant on New Year's Eve. Marjory Collins (1912-1985), photographer • December 31 1942

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog]  Agreed ... I'd like to find the original this was cropped from.  It almost looks like 'early'  photo manipulation, given the lack of any apparent opening in his lips...

I think the next 4 photos may have been part of one original. In this photo, for instance, Lt. Com. Byrd was originally standing to the right of CommanderBellinger his left shoulder is in the Byrd picture:

These photos seem connected to the March, 1919 effort to fly NC seaplanes ("Nancies") across the Atlantic in competition with the British: "Three aircraft would attempt the trip, NC-1, NC-3 and NC-4. As NC-1 had been damaged during a March storm, one wing of the experimental NC-2 was used to refit it. To increase the margin of safety, a fourth pusher-type engine was added behind the original central engine. Next, the Navy selected crews to man the three planes, appointing Towers as commanding officer. Crews came from the Regular Navy, the Naval Reserve and the U.S. Coast Guard. Towers chose NC-3 as his flagship, and Richardson was picked as chief pilot. Patrick N.L. Bellinger was chosen as commander for NC-1 and Albert C. Read for NC-4. Marc Mitscher, originally picked to command the now scrubbed NC-2, became NC-1‘s pilot. In addition, the airplanes carried radio operators, flight engineers and mechanics. During WWI, Richard E. Byrd had experimented with a number of scientific instruments, ranging from drift indicators to bubble sextants, that were useful in navigating over water, without visual landmarks. Although Byrd lobbied hard to join the 1919 flight, instead the Navy assigned him to plan the navigation for the flying boats only as far as Trepassey Bay." more at www.historynet.com/aviation-history-three-us-flying-boats...

Have not found the exact photo this series was cropped from, but another taken at the same time is at www.history.navy.mil/our-collections/photography/us-peopl... with the caption: "Naval Aviation Board, preparing for the NC Trans-Atlantic Flight, 1919 Photographed while preparing for the trans-Atlantic flight of the NC Aircraft, circa spring 1919. Aviators are as follows: Lieutenant Commander Godfrey de C. Chevalier, USN, (Liaison and Assistant in Charge of Operations); Commander Holden C. Richardson, USN, (Construction); Lieutenant Roswell P. Barratt, USN, (Aerographer); Lieutenant Commander Patrick N. L. Bellinger, USN, (Navigation); Lieutenant Commander Richard E. Byrd, USN, (Navigation); Major Bernard L. Smith, USMC, (Material); and Commander John H. Towers, USN U.S. Naval History and Heritage Command Photograph"

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] Well, in that last photograph you found, as the saying goes, "there you have it"! Lieutenant Commander Richard E. Byrd, USN, is holding the cigarette (with cigarette holder), with the pencil behind his ear! Well done, Art Siegel! (as always). The cigarette in the first, cropped, photo seemed inappropriate, viz., not what an officer would do in a (formal) photograph. The photograph you found is more casual in nature and doesn't run up against my own sense of propriety as I think of that time, place and rank. Then again, these guys were flight crew ;) and if anyone would need easy access to a pencil as a tool for their job/responsibility it would be navigation planner Richard Byrd! (I love the swivel/adjustable candlestick phone holder!)

Robert Howard Lord doesn't seem to have an English Wikipedia entry, but does have a Polish one: pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Howard_Lord Translation via Google Translate: "Robert Howard Lord (b. 20 of July 1885 in Plano in the state of Illinois , d. 22 May 1954 in Brighton in the state of Massachusetts ) - American historian, a Roman Catholic. May 1, 1918 Lord was the manager of the American experts to Eastern affairs at the future peace conference. November 30, 1918 was appointed to the US delegation to the Paris Peace Conference as an adviser on Russia and Polish. At the time of the Versailles Conference were affected by President Woodrow Wilson , claiming that the restoration of the Polish state is repairing the greatest political crime, she knew Europe, the restoration of the principles of justice in international relations . He maintained that the Polish state should be rebuilt in its historical borders, and not ethnic. January 28, 1919 became a member of the commission to investigate the situation in Poland and in the disputed border territories . He sat in the Joint Commission for the Polish and Czechoslovak and the Subcommittee on Cieszyn region and the future eastern Polish border."

From the Catalogue of official A.E.F. photographs, 1919: "51713 [3078N9]. Fort Ehrenbreitstein is just across the river from the monument to Kaiser William I. The sloping rock on which it rests is, at the top, 400 feet above the river, and is said to have been at one time a Roman fort. Ehrenbreitstein was beseiged unsuccessfully by the French in 1688, but in 1799, on account of the failure of provisions, its garrison had to surrender to them and the fortress was razed. Between 1816 and 1826 it was restored at a cost of 8,000,000 thalers. In the foreground is a pontoon bridge called the Bridge of Boats. Pvt. Elgie Fisher, Headquarters Company, One hundred and twenty-first Machine Gun Battalion. Ehrenbreitstein, Germany. January 7, 1919." archive.org/stream/cu31924027944598/#page/n549/mode/2up

"FORDNEY, Joseph Warren, (1853 - 1932) FORDNEY, Joseph Warren, a Representative from Michigan; born on a farm near Hartford City, Blackford County, Ind., November 5, 1853; attended the common schools; moved to Saginaw, Saginaw County, Mich., in June 1869 and engaged in the lumber industry; afterward became the owner of extensive lumber enterprises; vice president of the Saginaw Board of Trade; member of the board of aldermen of Saginaw 1896-1900; elected as a Republican to the Fifty-sixth and to the eleven succeeding Congresses (March 4, 1899-March 3, 1923); chairman, Committee on Expenditures in the Department of the Navy (Fifty-ninth Congress), Committee on Ways and Means (Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh Congresses); co-sponsor of the Fordney-McCumber Tariff of 1922; declined to be a candidate for renomination in 1922; delegate to the Republican National Convention in 1908; returned to the lumber business in Saginaw, Mich.; also interested in banking and agricultural pursuits; died in Saginaw, Mich., on January 8, 1932; interment in St. Andrew’s Cemetery. Bibliography Russell, John A. Joseph Warren Fordney: An American Legislator. Boston: The Stratford Co., 1928." bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=F000271

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cary_T._Grayson "Rear Admiral Cary Travers Grayson (October 11, 1878 – February 15, 1938) was a surgeon in the United States Navy who served a variety of roles from personal aide to President Woodrow Wilson to chairman of the American Red Cross." "Grayson's close personal relationship with Woodrow Wilson led to his commission as a Rear Admiral on August 29, 1916. "This rapid promotion of Dr. Grayson from Passed Assistant Surgeon with the rank of Lieutenant to Medical Director to the rank of Rear Admiral was unprecedented and was due to his position as White House Physician." Grayson resided in the White House. He accompanied Wilson and stayed near him while he attended peace talks in Paris in 1919."

USS George Washington (ID # 3018), 1917-1919. Originally S.S. George Washington (German Passenger Liner, 1908). www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/OnlineLibrary/photos/sh-usn/usns... This ship took President Woodrow Wilson to France and back twice in late 1918 and the first half of 1919 to the Peace Conference in Paris. The Commanding Officer for at least some of these voyages was Captain Edward McCauley, identified as sitting just to the left of the President in www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/OnlineLibrary/photos/images/h530... and also shown in www.flickr.com/photos/wwplarchives/5434101220/in/album-72... Probably J. Dickinson Este in that group: "Jonathan Dickinson Este, was born on March 12, 1887 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, and died on September 25, 1961 in Fairfield, Connecticut. A graduate of Princeton University,[1] he served with distinction as an aviator in World War I. He shot down four enemy aircraft, won the Distinguished Service Cross, and commanded the 13th Aero Squadron for the last few weeks of the war." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Dickinson_Este "ESTE, J. DICKINSON First Lieutenant (Air Service), U.S. Army Pilot, 13th Aero Squadron, 2d Pursuit Group, Air Service, A.E.F. Date of Action: September 13, 1918 Citation: The Distinguished Service Cross is presented to J. Dickinson Este, First Lieutenant (Air Service), U.S. Army, for extraordinary heroism in action near Chambley, France, September 13, 1918. First Lieutenant Este was leading an offensive patrol of five machines when a formation of seven enemy single-seaters approached the patrol from above. Although outnumbered and in a very disadvantageous position, he did not hesitate to lead his patrol to the attack. Through the combat which followed he fought with the greatest bravery, in spite of the fact that he was himself attacked by two enemy planes, which fired at his at point-blank range from the rear and above. By his skill and courage he was able to keep his formation together, and they succeeded in shooting down three of the enemy planes, of which h himself destroyed one and drove down another out of control. General Orders No. No. 123, W.D., 1918 Birth: Philadelphia, PA Home Town: Haverford, PA" www.homeofheroes.com/members/02_DSC/citatons/01_wwi_dsc/d... also "Edward Vernon Rickenbacker (October 8, 1890 – July 23, 1973) was an American fighter ace in World War I and Medal of Honor recipient. With 26 aerial victories, he was America's most successful fighter ace in the war." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eddie_Rickenbacker details of his seven DSC awards at www.homeofheroes.com/members/02_DSC/citatons/01_wwi_dsc/d... also "BREWSTER, HUGH First Lieutenant (Air Service), U.S. Army Pilot, 49th Aero Squadron, 2d Pursuit Group, Air Service, A.E.F. Date of Action: September 14, 1918 Citation: The Distinguished Service Cross is presented to Hugh Brewster, First Lieutenant (Air Service), U.S. Army, for extraordinary heroism in action in the region of Hageville, France, September 14, 1918. With First Lieutenant Hugh L. Fontaine, First Lieutenant Brewster attacked nine enemy monoplanes (Fokkers) at an altitude of 4, 000 meters. He dived into the midst of the enemy formation without consideration for his personal safety, subjecting himself to great danger. By the suddenness and extreme vehemence of his attack, the machines were driven into confusion. Although greatly outnumbered, he and Lieutenant Fontaine succeeded in shooting down two of the enemy. General Orders No. No. 123, W.D., 1918 Birth: Bankston, AL Home Town: Fort Worth, TX" www.homeofheroes.com/members/02_DSC/citatons/01_wwi_dsc/d... also "D'OLIVE, CHARLES RUDOLPH First Lieutenant (Air Service), U.S. Army Pilot, 93d Aero Squadron, 3d Pursuit Group, Air Service, A.E.F. Outnumbered and fighting against tremendous odds, he shot down three enemy planes and outfought the entire enemy formation. General Orders No. No. 123, W.D., 1918 Birth: 7/10/1896 - Suggsville, AL Home Town: Memphis, TN" www.homeofheroes.com/members/02_DSC/citatons/01_wwi_dsc/d... Rath, Second Lieutenant (Air Service), U.S. Army, for extraordinary heroism in action between Chambley and Xammes, France, September 13, 1918. (First Award) First Lieutenant (Air Service), U.S. Army Pilot, 147th Aero Squadron, 1st Pursuit Group, Air Service, A.E.F. Date of Action: September 16, 1918 Citation: The Distinguished Service Cross is presented to Louis C. Simon, Jr., First Lieutenant (Air Service), U.S. Army, for extraordinary heroism in action in the region of Hadonville-les-La-Chausse, France, September 16, 1918. While on a protection patrol for American observation planes from the 99th Aero Squadron, Lieutenant Simon was fired upon by three Halberstadt biplane fighters. Regardless of his personal danger, he immediately engaged the enemy, although alone, drawing them down and away from the observation planes which continued their important work unmolested. Lieutenant Simon continued fighting the three Halberstadts fiercely in spite of the odds against him. He finally succeeded in getting on the tail of one; and, after firing a short burst at close range, the enemy plane fell out of control. The remaining two planes quickly broke off the combat and headed east with motors full on. Simon, Jr., First Lieutenant (Air Service), U.S. Army, for extraordinary heroism in action near Cierges, France, October 23, 1918. Lieutenant Simon and two other pilots encountered nine (type Fokker) enemy planes, which were protecting an observation plane (type Rumpler). Lieutenant Simon attacked the lower formation of four planes alone and drove them off. He next dived at the observation plane and sent it crashing to the ground in flames. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Russia_Intervention "The North Russia Intervention, also known as the Northern Russian Expedition, the Archangel Campaign, and the Murman Deployment, was part of the Allied Intervention in Russia after the October Revolution. ... The campaign lasted from 1918, during the final months of World War I, to 1920." "In July 1918, against the advice of the US War Department, Wilson agreed to a limited participation in the campaign by a contingent of U.S. Army soldiers of the 339th Infantry Regiment, that was hastily organized into the American North Russia Expeditionary Force, which came to be nicknamed the Polar Bear Expedition. Under his Aide Memoire, Wilson set the guidelines for American intervention by saying the purpose of American troops in Russia was "to guard military stores which may subsequently be needed by Russian forces and to render such aid as may be acceptable to the Russians in the organization of their own self-defense.""

D.) of the United States Army soon became a familiar sight in Archangel's principal streets. In the background is seen the city's famous cathedral, the domes and spires of which glitter with gold leaf."

The Reluctant Tourist, by Ronald Barnett, page 90 books.google.com/books?id=VnQFPvWjstcC&pg=PA90&lp... Indicates that this street would be "Trotsky Prospekt," renamed after the revolution, and the location of the British Consulate. Leslie's Photographic Review of the Great War books.google.com/books?id=ep1GAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PT68&am... published this photo or one taken at the same time, captioned, "Trotsky Prospect, one of the main streets in Archangel. In the background stands one of the city's numerous churches. The domes and tall spires of these churches all glitter with gold leaf." The finding aid for the United States Army Signal Corps photograph collection: 1918-1919 at Bentley Historical Library (University of MIchigan) quod.lib.umich.edu/b/bhlead/umich-bhl-921010?view=text shows a very similar caption for Signal Corps photo 39147 (this photo).

Today, Google maps shows the street as "просп. Троицкий" transliterated as "Troitskiy pr.". I found no churches on Streetview. www.oldstratforduponavon.com/archangel.html has postcards of Archangel/Arkhangelsk with several of this street. So far, I have not been able to identify its previous name.
According to Wisconsin Historical Images, this is the Church of Rojdestva Kristova (Nativity of Christ) near Archangel www.flickr.com/photos/whsimages/11949706146/

Trying to track down the church by name, I find a Prokudin-Gorskii photograph www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/prokc.21061/ looks somewhat similar. It has the caption T︠S︡erkovʹ vo imi︠a︡ Rozhdestva Khristova v Krokhini︠e︡. [Rossiĭskai︠a︡ imperii︠a︡] translated as Church of the Nativity of Christ, in Krokhino. [Russian Empire]. But Krokhino is 697 km from Arkhangelsk according to Google maps.

But the different transliteration does find the right church, at sobory.ru/article/?object=34112 and confirm its name as the Church of the Nativity. The metadata includes coordinates. If they are correct, Streetview of the location is www.google.com/maps/@64.5350028,40.5224022,3a,75y,223.84h...

In 1919, employers at a Barcelona hydroelectric plant, known locally as La Canadiense, cut wages, triggering a 44-day-long and hugely successful general strike with over 100,000 participants. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anarchism_in_Spain#General_Strike_o...

The 14 men are identified (with some variations from the Tribune story) in the New York Times for February 24, 1919. Jose Grau, 25, editor of the radical Spanish language newspaper "El Corsario" and uses the pen name of "Arnaldo Sapelana". Jose (or Joseph) Roman (or Ramon) Fernandez, 21, laborer. Jose M. Alicer, 22, cigarmaker. Raphael Acosta, 24, cigarmaker. Joseph Micezer, 20, clerk Alemanero Malcono, twenty years old, pantryman. Celestino Granado (or Granada), 22, cigarmaker Ramon Sanchez, 23, cigarmaker Rogelio Garcia, 26, cigarmaker Theodore (or Pedro) Martin,29, associate editor and business manager of "El Corsario," Elario Orestissa, 39, machinist. Federico Madini [or Medina or Bertier], 23, machinist, Placido Santa Maria, 29, kitchenman, Florian Medina [Bertier] (brother of Federico), 24, chemist. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A0CE2D71139E1...

The Norwich bulletin., September 25, 1919, p. 1, col. 5, "COUNSEL FOR GRAU DENIES CLIENT IS A SPANISH I. W. W.", confirms that Jose Grau was merely alleged by the immigration authorities to have entered the United States secretly in order to attend a convention of the I.W.W. in Philadelphia. He was detained at Ellis Island for deportation. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014086/1919-09-25/ed-...

Marguerite Sylva (also known as Marguerita Sylva) (10 July 1875 – 21 February 1957), Belgian born mezzo-soprano en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marguerite_Sylva
see also

In early 1919, Sylva was playing vaudeville. See, e.g., New-York Tribune., May 11, 1919, Image 37, column 2 (Palace ) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1919-05-11/ed-... and [Washington] Evening Star., January 05, 1919, Page 7, ad in column 1 (B.F. Keith's) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1919-01-05/ed-...

Hollywood, Volume 11, July 22, 1922 books.google.com/books?id=fhpSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PT178&l... has a piece about Sylva singing at the Hollywood Bowl. The piece mentions her daughters, calling them "Daphne Sylva Smith, age four, who was here with her, and Marguerita Sylva Smith, not yet two years of age." If those detail are correct, this photo would have to be taken later than 1919, since the girls look to be about 1 and 3 here. But another article, in Musical America, March 5, 1921, books.google.com/books?id=pjg_AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA67&am... has the girls as "Daphne and Sylva, aged four and five, respectively." The two articles differ as to the girls' ages and also as to which is older! Looking further, The Musical Monitor, Volume 10, September 1921 books.google.com/books?id=N3NFAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA585&l... has them as "Sylva, nearly five, and Daphne, two years younger." I should have searched on Flickr sooner. See comments on . It seems most likely that Daphne is the younger and was born in December 1917. So this picture probably is from early 1919. The older girl seems to have been known as Sylva when young.
Listen to her as Carmen at www.library.ucsb.edu/OBJID/Cylinder2364 Other recordings at cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?queryType=%40attr+1....

Sylva's 1957 obituary www.nytimes.com/1957/02/22/archives/mme-sylva-81-exopera-... names her daughters as "Leslie, a fashion designer, and Daphne, a former actress and singer." They were both living in New York state.
Thanks swanq for researching the birthdates of the two children which helps get a more precise date for the image. We will add more details when we update.

Was this a TB isolation school?

My guess is that it may be just very cold and the windows were opened to make the poor children and teacher suffer even more. The class room seems to be too large to be heated by an open fire which would cause air pollution and getting enough wood every day in Chicago for all of the classrooms throughout winter would have cost a fortune, not to mention the storage problem such a large pile of wood would cause.

I like the idea of the cloth 'shades' covering the open windows thus preventing cold air blowing onto the children. Also, they actually act like probably unintended light boxes for the photograph. And, the kids were told to look busy writing something. So they, especially the two children in the foreground, put the pencil on any part of the already printed sheet. I went to school (in Europe) in the late 1950's and for every school photo we had to put a pencil on a sheet of paper pretending to be writing something. Every child was given the same pencil and the same sheet of paper. :)

very nice photo and blog post. for the not so curious, this was from the "open air" schools rule - so that you could avoid the spread of tuberculosis with constant ventilation. apperently it was in a cold season... :) poor kids and teachers. the post is really nice and have some other cool stories and photos!

This appears to be an example of one of the open air schools, which was a movement in the early part of the 20th century. It was designed decrease the spread of tuberculosis and promote health by exposing kids to "fresh air." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_air_school

Prokofiev died at the age of 61 on 5 March 1953, the same day as Joseph Stalin. He had lived near Red Square, and for three days the throngs gathered to mourn Stalin, making it impossible to carry Prokofiev's body out for the funeral service at the headquarters of the Soviet Composers' Union. He is buried in the Novodevichy Cemetery in Moscow.He was an atheist.

Brigadier-General LeRoy Sunderland Upton (1869-1927), of the 57th Infantry Brigade
He was born 8 October 1869 in Michigan.

His correct name is LaRoy Sunderland Upton valor.militarytimes.com/recipient.php?recipientid=15700 According to www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=139778006, he was a nephew of General Emory Upton (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emory_Upton) He died on March 1, 1927 at Honolulu fultonhistory.com/highlighter/viewer/?file=http%3A%2F%2Ff...

From Catalogue of official A.E.F. photographs (1919): "38456. Brig. Gen. Leroy S. Upton (D. S. C), commanding Fifty-seventh Brigade, Twenty-ninth Division, First Army. Passavant, Marne, France. November 26, 1918. " archive.org/stream/cu31924027944598#page/n425/mode/2up
It looks to be spelled in different places both LaRoy and Leroy. We will leave it with the original Bain spelling. Thanks for the comments!

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/141808192@N06] For his name see also - socialarchive.iath.virginia.edu/ark:/99166/w64f6djz - catalog.archives.gov/id/10598490 - bscstudent.buffalostate.edu/browcn77/web/ProfCertThesis.pdf It is true that his name was sometimes spelled "Leroy" (in newspapers etc.), which is not surprising since "Leroy" is much more common than "LaRoy". But the fact that all authoritative sources call him LaRoy indicates IMO that this is the correct name and all other notations are erroneous.
LOC has him as LaRoy in its Name Authority File: "Upton, LaRoy Sunderland, 1869-1927 From Library of Congress Name Authority File" id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2009188213.html

Artist: www.askart.com/artist/Louis_Mark/29281/Louis_Mark.aspx www.artprice.com/artist/54060/louis-mark/biography From the former: "A portrait painter, Louis Mark was born in Retteg, Hungary on August 25, 1867. He studied in Paris with Bouguereau and Robert-Fleury, and from 1910 to 1922, did portrait commissions in principal cities in the United States." Name variant: Lajos Mark From the latter: Louis MARK (1867-1942) Birth place: Hungary Death place: NYC Profession: Portrait painter Studied: Académie Julian, Paris with Bouguereau and Robert-Fleury, 1890-93. Exhibited: Munich, 1890; Vienna, 1894; Exposition Universelle, Paris, 1900 (silver med.) Comments: He came to the U.S. in 1910 and fulfilled portrait commissions in major cities until 1922.

The portrait is a view of Wilson as academic, rather than as president of the U.S. He was President of Princeton University, from 1902 to 1910, and then the 34th Governor of New Jersey, serving from 1911 to 1913. It also seems to be of a younger man. See millercenter.org/president/biography/wilson-life-before-t... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson It seems likely that the portrait dates from 1910 or perhaps earlier, if Mark came to the U.S. to visit before he came permanently in 1910, or Wilson sat/stood for Mark in Europe.
I wonder why he drew in a skull and Jesus on the cross?

Seattle, WA police chief in the news in 1919 for his handling of General Strike: "Warren, Joel Franklin (1858-1934) "The Seattle General Strike The Seattle General Strike had its origin in the support of union workers around the city for striking shipyard workers. The strike began at 10 a.m. on February 6, 1919, and lasted for four days. Sixty thousand workers went off their jobs and brought to Seattle an almost complete cessation of business. Warren prepared for the strike by hiring hundreds of University of Washington fraternity men and deputizing them as special officers. Also, a contingent of troops from Camp Lewis was on hand. Throughout the strike there was no public disorder and police reported fewer calls than usual. Labor remembered Warren’s reputation as a strikebreaker in Idaho 26 years earlier and criticized his tactics in the Seattle General Strike. On February 9, 1919, he ordered a raid on Socialist Party headquarters, arresting three men for circulating the party’s newspaper. Next he raided the IWW (Industrial Workers of the World) hall and arrested 39 men because he was "tired of reading their revolutionary circulars." Earlier he had ordered the breakup of a parade of 500 "Reds" and arrested 13 without charge. During the General Strike he closed a print shop for printing radical literature. Later he placed officers on the premises to censor anything that might be printed. All of this was done under a city ordinance that gave the police chief discretion if, in his judgment, actions were taken for "unlawful purposes" (Berner)" www.historylink.org/File/964

I found a few photos of Dr. Steen, and while they were taken after this one (in the 1920's and 1930's) I don't think it's the same man. For one he's bald on the top of head, and this man has a very full head of hair. Also an undigitized photo we have  shows a good profile view of Dr. Steen. He has larger ears and a larger, hooked nose.

Gordon Auchincloss, 1886-1943, NYT obit from findagrave.com: "AUCHINCLOSS DIES; AIDE TO COL. HOUSE New York Attorney Acted as Secretary to Father-in-Law at Peace Conference SERVED IN FEDERAL POSTS Was Special Assistant to the Attorney General, Later in the State Department Gordon Auchincloss, lawyer and former secretary to his father-in-law, the late Colonel Edward M. House, adviser of President Woodrow Wilson, died yesterday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after an illness of several months. His age was 56. Mr. Auchincloss was a member of the law firm of Auchincloss, Alley & Duncan of 50 Broadway. He served as secretary of the American War Mission to England and France in November, 1917, and as secretary to Colonel House during negotiations of the Armistice in November, 1918, and during the Peace Conference in Paris in 1919. Born in New York, he was the son of Edgar Stirling and Maria LaGrange Sloan Auchincloss, and a grandson of Samuel Sloan, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna & Western Railroad and of the Hudson River Railroad, predecessor of the New York Central System. Prepared at Groton Graduated from Groton School in 1904, he received an A. B. degree from Yale University in 1908 and an LL. B. degree from Harvard Law School in 1911. He began practice in New Tork and served as assistant United States attorney for the Southern District, New York, from 1913 to 1915, and as special assistant to the Attorney General of the United States in charge of certain tax litigation from 1915 to 1917. He was assistant treasurer of the Democratic National Committee in 1916. In May, 1917, he was appointed an assistant to the counselor of the State Department and later accompanied Colonel House to Europe. Mr. Auchincloss was a director of the Chase National Bank, International Paper and Power Company, the Crosse & Blackwell Company. societe Financiere de Transports et d'Enterprises Industrielles of Brussels, Belgium; Solvay American Corporation and Compania Hispano Americana de Electicidad of Barcelona, Spain. Had Acted as Receiver He had been trustee and receiver in many large financial reorganizations and bankruptcies. He was receiver for Zimmerman & Forshay, bankers and brokers, in 1923, for the Hodgman Rubber Company in 1924 and for the Eastern Insull units in 1932, trustee in the American bankruptcy proceedings for the Kreuger & Toll Company in 1932 and for the Porto-Rican-American Tobacco Company in 1940, later becoming president of the reorganized company, the Rican Corporation. Mr. Auchincloss was chairman of the fund raising committee of the New York Association for the Blind and a trustee of the Riverside Church. He was a member of the State and city bar associations, Psi Upsilon and Scroll and Key of Yale. His clubs included the Links and Broad Street of New York and Piping Rock of Locust Valley, L.I. Mr. Auchincloss resided in Locust Valley and had a town house at 950 Park Avenue. He leaves a widow, the former Janet House; a son, Edward House Auchincloss; a daughter, Mrs. Louise Robbins of Washington, D.C., and four brothers, Representative James C. Auchincloss of Rumson, N.J. and Charles, Reginald and Dr. Hugh Auchincloss, all of New York. The New York Times - New York, NY - 17 Apr 1943" www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=AUCHIN...;

Why so many uniformed men in that crowd? What kind of occasion was that?

@Aldis Putelis.
That will be the crowd celebrating the Armistice at the end of WW1, almost all able bodied men were in the services, and therefore in uniform.

It doesn't appear to be Armistice celebrations. The crowd is standing quietly (and still) behind police lines and everyone's looking into Trafalgar Square. Waiting for someone or for something to happen? Interesting to see the press of people on the wall at Charing Cross Station in the background. They seem much keener to see whatever's going on than the people standing on the Strand.

Likely at the visit of President Wilson. ""President Wilson's journey was a triumphal procession from the moment he landed," says the Mail, "and it was real sincere affection and no mere curiosity that brought to his ears the acclamation of the people of London. There have been more excited crowds here, but never crowds that so impressively expressed their warmhearted hospitality."" Thomas L. Delahunty was the head of the Marine Workers union and led a harbor strike in New York in the spring of 1919. He died in December, 1919. books.google.com/books?id=B_dYAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA10-PA30&a... query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A02E3D8123BEE...
Resolution of the harbor strike was taken up by the National War Labor Board (adjacent photos) in January, 1919. see

Thomas Lawrence Delahunty, President of the Marine Workers' Affiliation and leader of the harbor strike last Spring, died yesterday of heart disease in Charleston, South Carolina, where he was visiting his mother. He was 52 years old and made his home with his daughter at 1,450 Fifty-ninth Street, Brooklyn. A marine engineer by trade. he had followed the sea for twenty-five years, visiting nearly every country in the world. During his eight years as a union official he had brought about many reforms In the condition of his fellow workers. 
(Source: New York Times on December 16, 1919)

SS Leviathan, originally built as the Vaterland, was an ocean liner which regularly crossed the North Atlantic from 1914 to 1934. The second of three sister ships built for Germany's Hamburg America Line for their transatlantic passenger service, she sailed as the Vaterland for less than a year before her early career was halted by the start of World War I. In 1917, she was seized by the U.S. government and renamed Leviathan. She would become known by this name for the majority of her career, both as a troopship during World War I and later as the flagship of the United States Lines. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Leviathan

"Frederick William (German: Friedrich Wilhelm) (16 February 1620 – 29 April 1688) was Elector of Brandenburg and Duke of Prussia – and thus ruler of Brandenburg-Prussia – from 1640 until his death. A member of the House of Hohenzollern, he is popularly known as "the Great Elector"[1] (der Große Kurfürst) because of his military and political achievements. Frederick William was a staunch pillar of the Calvinist faith, associated with the rising commercial class. He saw the importance of trade and promoted it vigorously. His shrewd domestic reforms gave Prussia a strong position in the post-Westphalian political order of north-central Europe, setting Prussia up for elevation from duchy to kingdom, achieved under his son and successor." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_William,_Elector_of_Brand...

From the IWM site: "THE GERMAN SPRING OFFENSIVE, MARCH-JULY 1918 part of "AMERICAN FIRST WORLD WAR OFFICIAL EXCHANGE COLLECTION" (photographs) Made by: US official photographer 1918-07-25 Troops of the American 326th Regiment moving forward German trenches at Choloy, 25 July 1918." THE GERMAN SPRING OFFENSIVE, MARCH-JULY 1918© IWM (Q 70733) see also

Thanks Art Siegel. I looked up the caption in the "Catalogue of Official A.E.F. Photographs" and it's nearly the same at the Getty one. The only difference is they list the date at August 1, 1918. I looked through book about a soldier from the M Company, "In White Armor,  the Life of Captain Arthur Ellis Hamm" and it confirms what I read elsewhere, that the 326th's first real combat was on August 4th. The book does mention that they did a "dress rehearsal" before the attack (they don't give a date). I would guess that this is the "dress rehearsal" because of the date and that the camera man appears to have followed the troops across no man's land.

That book is a great resource.. didn't know about it. I see there are captions there for some other Bain photos which give either an identification or extra details beyond the previous crowdsource research. Dress rehearsal with (presumably) dummy ordnance does seem likely, certainly safer for official photographer. So, definitely 326th and not 336th. Here's another from the series: THE GERMAN SPRING OFFENSIVE, MARCH-JULY 1918© IWM (Q 58205)

"The Chinese Labour Corps (CLC; French: Corps de Travailleurs Chinois) was a force of workers recruited by the British government in World War I to free troops for front line duty by performing support work and manual labour. The French government also recruited a significant number of Chinese labourers, and although those labourers working for the French were recruited separately and not part of the CLC, they are often considered to be so. In all, some 140,000 men served for both British and French forces before the war ended and most of the men were repatriated to China between 1918 and 1920. " en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Labour_Corps

Note the "Soldatenheim" and the Canteen." THE HUNDRED DAYS OFFENSIVE, AUGUST-NOVEMBER 1918© IWM (Q 11274)

The signs on the houses are "Soldatenheim" (soldier's home),  "Eingang" (entrance) and "Marketenderei" (sutlery), s. notes. I can't read the other signs, but I don't see a "Kantine" (canteen). The Soldatenheim IS the canteen.

A board with the inscription: "Nicht ärgern, nur wundern!" (Don't be angry, just be amazed) was left by the Germans on the destroyed town hall, but it's not there anymore on this photo. S. www.columbia.edu/itc/history/winter/w3206/edit/destroyedt...

From the IWM's March, 1917 photo showing the sign: "Wrecked building on the Grande Place, showing German notice "Don't be annoyed: just marvel". The sign is now in possession of the Imperial War Museum. " THE GERMAN WITHDRAWAL TO THE HINDENBURG LINE, MARCH-APRIL 1917© IWM (Q 4965)

The sign is not in the online IWM collection, but here is its description there: "History note translation " Don't rage, only wonder!", this sign was found suspended from a building in the Grand Place at Peronne on the entry of British troops on 18/3/17. The Germans had withdrawn to the Hindenburg Line destroying all habitable buildings, wells, orchards etc in the area previously occupied by them. Photo in loan file Painted Nicht argern, nur wundern!" www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/30028064

Russians in the front row were the soldiers either the Mensheviks or to any form of an anti socialist fraction.

S. Infantry. Highest officer killed in the World War. Detailed to lead a brigade to the front, he was mortally wounded September 29, 1918 and died in base hospital eight days later." archive.org/stream/ohioarchological31ohio/ohioarchologica... More at www.arlingtoncemetery.net/esigerfoos.htm

Brigadier General Edward Sigerfoos (December 14, 1868 – October 7, 1918) was a senior United States Army officer. From 1891 to 1918, his military service included a number of assignments in the continental United States, Cuba, the Philippines, China, and France. He saw active service in the Philippine–American War and World War I. While in France in 1918, he was nominated by President Woodrow Wilson for promotion to brigadier general. During the Meuse-Argonne Offensive, he was wounded mortally and died shortly before the United States Senate confirmed his nomination. He was promoted posthumously and was the only American general to have been killed in combat during the war. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Sigerfoos

A "Britain's Day" celebration on December 7, 1918 was planned to honor Britain's contributions to the war, with a public meeting planned at New York's Hippodrome for December 8. Artists James Montgomery Flagg and Carton Moorepark (sometimes Moore-Park) designed posters for the event. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E01E4D81E3BE0... Flagg's poster elsewhere on LOC site: www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/cph.3b49209/

However, the poster on the left is by F.G. Cooper. [Frederic G. Cooper] His monogram is visible on hi-res versions of the photo at lower right. " A poster done at the close of the war period was quite as unique from the standpoint of pictorial design as his Food Administration posters had been for their lettering.This was America's Tribute to Britain issued on England's Day December 7th 1918. It showed the American eagle swooping low in its flight to drop a wreath of laurel on the head of the British lion. The design was archaistic and done in masses of black against the light background formed by a beautiful grained panel of wood. In the figures of the eagle and lion there was slight but clear delineation effected by firmly drawn lines of white against the mass of black. From a pictorial standpoint this was the most original design Cooper had executed up to that time. In all the annals of art, primitive and present, oriental and occidental, the precedent for that lion and that eagle cannot be found. In design, as in lettering therefore, Cooper's war period gave evidence of distinctive originality." The Poster, December 1, 1922 books.google.com/books?id=KTJGAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA10-PA6&am... Color reproduction at art.famsf.org/fg-cooper/americas-tribute-britain-world-wa...
The poster was created by James Montgomery Flagg, s. vepca.wordpress.com/tag/vepca-com/ www.loc.gov/item/2002712329/

Mabel Garrison (1886-1963) was a popular coloratura soprano.  "She made her Metropolitan Opera debut on February 15, 1914 in concert, singing arias from operas by Verdi and Mozart." [1] The cover of the catalog she is holding is "New Victor Records • November, 1918" which may provide further clues as to why these photos were in the news at this time..... she made several recordings for the Victor Talking Machine Company.  Mabel Garrison performed in "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Le Coq d'Or" at the Metropolitan Opera in 1918 as well as the "Twelfth Sunday Concert", "Nineteenth Sunday Concert" and a "Special Performance". [2]   A number of these recordings are available on You Tube in excellent quality. There are several photographs of Mabel Garrison in The Bain Collection.

Mabel Garrison (1886-1963) was a popular coloratura soprano. "She made her Metropolitan Opera debut on February 15, 1914 in concert, singing arias from operas by Verdi and Mozart." [1] Based on a catalog Ms. Garrison is holding in the photo below, apparently taken at the same time, the date of this photograph is likely November, 1918. There are several photographs of Mabel Garrison in The Bain Collection. [ "Mabel Garrison" by The Library of Congress ]

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mossley_Hill
A shot of the exterior of the hospital: AMERICAN FIRST WORLD WAR OFFICIAL EXCHANGE COLLECTION© IWM

"The first Red Cross Military Hospital for US Forces in Great Britain opened in 1918 in Mossley Hill in south Liverpool. It was ideally located – just 15 minutes from the docks where soldiers would be transported to and from the battlefield via boat. The original capacity was 25 to 50, based in an old manor house, but with the amount of casualties being brought back from the front line, this increased to 500 for both American, and allied injured servicemen. At the beginning of 1918, a flu pandemic brought further devastation, with 250,000 people losing their lives in England. Mossley Hill Hospital’s facilities were used to treat people who were suffering with the illness during this time. Following World War One, Mossley Hill Hospital became a War Pensions Hospital before joining the NHS after World War Two." www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p02vzwl4

This and several hundred other photos of U.S. American National Red Cross Hospital No.4 are in the U.S. National Library of Medicine online collection: collections.nlm.nih.gov/catalog/nlm:nlmuid-101404985-img

"The Palais Universitaire in Strasbourg is a large, neo-Renaissance style building, constructed between 1879 and 1884 under the direction of the German architect Otto Warth. It was inaugurated in 1884 by Wilhelm I, Emperor of Germany. Through Avenue de la Liberté (former Kaiser-Wilhelm-Straße), it faces the equally monumental former imperial palace (Kaiserpalast). The building served for several decades as the centre of the new imperial University of Strasbourg." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palais_Universitaire,_Strasbourg

At center in uniform, Gen. Anto Gvozdenović, ambassador of Montenegro to the United States. See He came to New York to participate in Liberty Loan ceremonies at the "Altar of Liberty"on October 11, 1918. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9404EFDD113BEE... The Altar of Liberty was a 25 by 100 foot structure built in September, 1918 in Madison Square, opposite the Worth Monument, to serve as the focal point of rallys for the Fourth Liberty Loan Campaign, including 22 Flag Days for various nations. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B00E3DC1F38E5...

Thank you for posting this wonderfully nostalgic, and well composed image. The vessel, when viewed under the higher definition image from the link mentioned: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.27688 quite clearly shows the name to be 'ALLIES'. Details for this vessel, as follows: Official Number 217581, was launched on 14 October 1918, by the Submarine Boat Company, Newark, New Jersey, USA (Hull no. 22), under the name 'ALLIES', being later completed on 'OQUAWKA', on 24 May 1919 for the United States Shipping Board. Vessel was a general cargo ship of a series, designated as the '1023' design, of 3,659 gross tons & 5,200 deadweight tons. The vessel had a short life, trading always under the name 'OQUAWKA', and was broken up by the Ford Motor Company, Philadelphia, arriving at the site on 24 September 1926.

One of a series of 12 Bain photos of the twin launching of SS Consort and SS Allies at the Submarine Boat Co. on Oct. 14, 1918: "TWO SHIPS NAMED IN HONOR OF ALLIES AT LAUNCHING THE Liberty Loan Committees of New York as a feature of the present Liberty Loan campaign arranged a special Allies Day, Monday October 14, to which were invited foreign ambassadors, Chairman Edward N Hurley of the United States Shipping Board and Commissioners John A. Donald, Bainbridge Colby, Charles R Page, Director Charles M Schwab of the Emergency Fleet Corporation, Charles Piez, vice president and general manager of Emergency Fleet Corporation and other Government officials. A special train left the Washington terminal at 7 30 AM on October 14, on which went the ambassadors and guests. Upon arrival at New York the party were met and entertained at a luncheon given by the Fifth Avenue Association at the Waldorf Astoria and at which addresses were made by Chairman Hurley, Director General Schwab, Governor Whitman and Governor Strong of the Federal Reserve Bank. Following the luncheon a special train took the guests to the Submarine Boat Yard at Newark NJ where there was a double launching of ships which were named in honor of the Allies. One of the ships was named Allies and the other Consort. Both are fabricated cargo vessels The special train brought the party back to Washington after the launching. Following are the ambassadors and ministers invited Mr JJ Jusserand, ambassador of the French Republic, Mr Domicio da Gama ambassador of Brazil, Count V Macchi di Cellere ambassador of Italy, Mr Boris Bakhmeteff ambassador of Russia , Mr Colville Barclay, charge d affaires ad interim of Great Britain, Viscount Kikukiro Ishii, Japanese ambassador, Viscount d Alte minister of Portugal, Senor Don Joaquin Mendez, minister of Guatemala, Phya Prabha Karavongse, Siamese minister, Mr Solon Menos, minister of Haiti, Dr Carlos Manuel de Cespedes, minister of Cuba, Mr Vi Kyuin Wellington Koo, the Chinese minister Senor Don JE Lefevre, charge d affaires of Panama, Mr E de Cartier de Marchienne, minister of Belgium, Mr George Roussos, minister of Greece, Senor Don J Antonio Lopez Gutierrez, minister of Honduras, Senor Don Diego Manuel Chamorro, minister of Nicaragua, Mr NH La hovary charge d affaires of Roumania, Mr Y Simitch, charge d affaires ad interim of Serbia, General Antoine Gvosdenovitch minister of Montenegro, Dr Toledo Herrarte, minister for foreign affairs of Guatemala, and Dr Policarpo Bonilla minister of Honduras on special mission." books.google.com/books?id=7ysuAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA10&am...

From www.balboaparkhistory.net/glimpses/scheink.htm "Henry Schumann-Heink and George Washington Schumann joined the U.S. Navy. Ferdinand Schumann became a member of the U.S. Army, 242nd Artillery at Camp Funston, Arizona. Walter Schumann enlisted as a cook in the U.S. Navy. The Army discharged Ferdinand after his lungs had been weakened by pneumonia. A German submarine torpedoed the transport George was on off the coast of France, but he survived. An American destroyer rammed the submarine August was on, June 15, 1918, resulting in the drowning of Schumann-Heink's eldest son. "

This is apparently Henry Hans Heink (1886 - 1951), son of Ernestine Schumann-Heink and her first husband Ernst Heink. www.geni.com/people/Henry-Hans-Heink/6000000020895034695 According to wikipedia: Erich Walther Heinrich Curt en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernestine_Schumann-Heink He is listed as "Henry Schumann Heink" in www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=142561436 and in billiongraves.com/burial-record/HENRY-SCHUMANN-HEINK/35272#

"As a naturalized American of Austrian origin, with a brother in command of an Austrian warship, her (Ernestine Schumann-Heink's) son August Heink in the German navy and her stepson Walter Schumann and sons Henry Heink and George Washington Schumann all in the American navy and with two sisters living in Germany, Schumann-Heink found her love for her new country clashed with that for the old." jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/schumann-heink-ernestine

The Topeka state journal., October 05, 1917, HOME EDITION, Page 6, col. 3 reported: "PROUD OF BOYS! - Every Son of Madam Schumann-Heink in Army. - ... Whole Family Fighting. There isn't a prouder mother in the world than madame. For all her male relatives are now wearing uniforms of one country or another. Ferdinand is here, George Washington Schumann is in the navy and is stationed at Goats Island; Henry Heink is in the naval reserve at Santiago; Walter Schumann Is In the coast artillery at Paterson, N. J., August Heink, when last heard from, was in command of the U-52, a German submarine; Hubert C. Guy, a son-in-law, is in the aviation section in California: another son-in-law is a physician in the German army; a brother of madame's also is a physician in the German army, and her father was a major in the Austrian cavalry." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016014/1917-10-05/ed-...

On the other hand, the Evening star., August 26, 1917, Image 49 published photos of Henry and his brother August with the caption: "The eternal tragedy of war has been brought home to Mme. Schumann-Heink, the singer. She has two sons in service on opposite sides. August Schumann-Heink (on right), the eldest son, is serving the kaiser in the German navy. Henry Schumann-Heink (on the left), the next son, is in the naval forces of the United States." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1917-08-26/ed-...

"Battle of Albert (21–23 August 1918) was the third battle by that name fought during World War I, following the First Battle of Albert and the Second Battle of Albert, with each of the series of three being fought roughly two years apart. This smaller third battle was significant in that it was the opening push that would lead to the Second Battle of the Somme and involved the Australian Corps." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Albert_(1918)

"The Canon de 155 Grande Puissance Filloux (GPF) mle.1917 was a 155 mm cannon used by the French Army during the first half of the 20th century. This gun was designed by French one Colonel L.J.F. Filloux to fill a vital French Army requirement for a heavy artillery piece. The design proved a success and became the standard heavy field gun of the French from 1917 through to the end of World War II. This weapon was pressed into service as soon as it was made ready to stabilize the shortage of such weapons in the French inventory. This weapon became the "Canon de 155 Grande Puissance Filloux mle 1917", named by French Army as the Canon de 155mm GPF (Model of 1917). During World War 1, the gun was eventually taken on by the American Expeditionary Force as a standard long-range artillery piece.[3] At the beginning of World War II the French guns were pulled out of reserve storage, and 24 of these guns were mobilized/on active duty in May-June 1940." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canon_de_155mm_GPF

"The Four Minute Men were a nation wide organization of public speakers under Government control during the period of America's participation in the World War Although the idea and early plans for the Four Minute Men originated in Chicago in the early part of April 1917 the work officially became a division of the Committee on Public Information on June 16 1917 when the national headquarters were removed to Washington The national organization and all its branches ended official existence on December 241 1918 Between these dates the Four Minute Men of America numbering about 75,000 speakers throughout 37 speaking campaigns delivered over 750,000 speeches to audiences totalling 315,000,000 persons The speeches were delivered almost exclusively in the motion picture theatres of the country during four minute intermissions The work was organized in 7,448 cities and towns including every State in the Union." books.google.com/books?id=SvQ-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA43&lp...

Березовка, район ст. Дивизионная, сейчас он называется поселок Вагжанова, недалеко от Улан-Удэ( бывший Верхнеудинск). Там вплоть до конца 1918 и начало 1919 года на базе армейских казарм находился лагерь для военнопленных Австро-Венгрии. После отправки военнопленных в 1918-19 году домой или другой лагерь, казармы занял 27-й пехотный полк армии США, под управлением полковника Ч. Морроу.

Thanks [https://www.flickr.com/photos/200750735@N06]. The date on the negative is October 8, 1918, but it's a copy negative (they made the negative by photographing an existing photo) so the date of the original photo could be earlier. They do appear to be wearing Austro-Hungarian uniforms, so we'll add a note identifying them as such.

Дата вполне реальная!!! Так, как 27 пехотный полк армии США, появился в Верхнеудинске (Улан-Удэ) в 1919 году. Два батальона солдат армии США получили формальное разрешение от администрации и населения Верхнеудинска на присутствие здесь американских войск. В общей сложности на территории от нынешнего Улан-Удэ до ст. Мысовой железную дорогу охраняли (это было главной задачей американцев) 2 тысячи американских солдат.
Кстати, на родине ветераны воевавшего в Сибири 27-го полка регулярно проводили встречи. Последняя такая встреча состоялась в 1985 году.

Что касаемо фото, то здесь изображены в основном цыгане из Австро-Венгрии, так как именно цыгане были хорошими уличными музыкантами!!! Вам в помощь венгерский источник, там есть это фото. nagyhaboru.blog.hu/2022/01/26/a_nagy_haboru_orosz_fogsagb...

Judging from en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice_Roosevelt_Longworth#/media/Fi... , a picture of the family in 1903, I think the woman at the right is his daughter, Ethel. Perhaps the young woman between Teddy and his second wife, Edith, is a daughter-in-law. Ethel married in 1913 and in 1918 would have had two children, Richard would have been 4 and Edith 1. Her brother Archie, married Grace Lockwood in 1917, and their son, Archie, Jr. was born in February 1918. Brother Kermit married Belle Wyatt Willard in 1914, and their second child, Joseph, was born in January 1918. So there are a couple of possibilities for the child Teddy is holding -- assuming this is from 1918. This picture was published in the Daily Mail in 2011. www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2066763/Teddy-Roosevelts... Its caption indicates that Teddy is indeed holding Archie, Jr., with Grace looking on and that the others are Ethel Derby, with her children, Richard and Edith.
This photo is in www.nps.gov/ner/photosmultimedia/photogallery.htm?id=D278... as well, with the same names.

Lieutenant General Sir Frederick Stanley Maude KCB, CMG, DSO (24 June 1864 – 18 November 1917) was a British Army officer. He is known for his operations in the Mesopotamian campaign during the First World War and for conquering Baghdad in 1917. He was the last man evacuated from Suvla Bay in the Dardanelles campaign. By Novembe 1917r his forces were engaged at Ramadi and Tikrit when he became ill from cholera (which some sources claim to have been caught from drinking unboiled milk) and abruptly died. Coincidentally, he died in the same house as German Field Marshal von der Goltz nineteen months earlier. General Marshall succeeded him. Mount Maude, a peak in the Cascade Range, was named for Frederick Maude by Albert H. Sylvester.[9] In 2003, the British military headquarters in Baghdad's Green Zone was named "Maude House". Maude is buried in Baghdad (North Gate) War Cemetery. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_Stanley_Maude

Capt Robert McGhee Graham "Today, the University of Missouri’s Memorial Union is a campus icon that remembers soldiers who died in battle. The concept came from a poem written by a MU College of Agriculture graduate who perished in World War I. Robert McGhee “Peaches” Graham (1892 – 1918) and his Army friends wrote the poem, which calls for the construction of a bell tower on the MU campus to memorialize the University’s war dead. His poem also suggested naming MU’s football stadium Memorial Stadium. Graham was a native of Montgomery County, Mo. He came from a Scottish pioneer family who ran farms on land originally owned by Daniel Boone. Family orchards earned him his nickname while attending Mizzou from 1911 to 1915. Graham is said to have been one of the most popular students on campus, active in student life and bubbling with ideas to improve his school. He played center during his senior year as a varsity football player. After earning his Bachelor of Science degree from the College of Agriculture he began graduate work in the school’s Department of Veterinary Medicine, intending to earn his living as a veterinarian. He left MU to return home and run one of the family farms. Farmers were excluded from service in World War I, but Graham turned down that exemption and enlisted in August 1917. He was commissioned as a captain in the U.S. Army, and his regiment was sent to France in 1918 where he wrote the poem. He mailed the manuscript back to MU faculty with a plea not to forget the soldiers. Graham was killed in action while patrolling enemy lines at St. Pie on July 27, 1918. " more at: cafnrnews.com/2013/12/a-poem-to-remember/

"James Edward Mahoney (December 15, 1858 – June 9, 1926) was an American officer born in Peabody, Massachusetts and serving in the United States Marine Corps during the Spanish–American War who was one of 23 Marine Corps officers approved to receive the Marine Corps Brevet Medal for bravery. He graduated from the United States Naval Academy in 1881. He subsequently served in Panama, Veracruz, Mexico, and in Cuba. After promotion to temporary rank of Brigadier General, he retired as a Colonel of Marines in 1919." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_E._Mahoney Promotion to temporary brigadier general, July 31, 1918 query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=980DE4DE1739E1...

Lt. Robert H. Flansburg "Birth: Feb. 1, 1893 Death: Jun. 15, 1918 Mrs. M. A. Youngs, 4306 Oakenwald avenue, yesterday received word that her nephew, Lieut. Robert H. Flansburg was killed in action in France June 15. Lieut. Flansburg was a postgraduate student in the law department at the University of Chicago when the United states entered the war. He entered the officers' school at Fort Snelling and received a lieutenant's commission. He was a son of C. C. Flansburg, an attorney of Lincoln, Neb., and a grandson of the late Adj. Nelson Flansburg, widely known among Illinois G. A. R. veterans. He was 24 years old. Chicago Tribune (IL) - June 27, 1918 " www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=69926096
