Abigail (Abby) Aldrich Rockefeller The August 16, 1918 Evening World notes Mrs. John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Driving First Spike Into the Keel of the U. S. Trawler Fish Hawk. Though that photo/article was probably at the boat's launching, not keel laying. The June 15 issue of Shipping noted that Fish Hawk was nearly all planked out and that launching would likely be in a few weeks. The July issue of The Rudder notes that Fish Hawk is the second of six planned trawlers for the East Coast Fisheries Company built in Maine by the Portland Shipbuilding Company and that Fish Hawk is a sistership to the first, the Kingfisher. The Rudder article includes some good plan and profile drawings of the boats. In the September, 1919 issue of The American Marine Engineerwe learn that while Kingfisher was sunk by a U-Boat during the war, Fish Hawk and her sisterships were still bringing fish into New York and the 6th in the series was about to begin construction.

Some photos of the Fish Hawk from 1919: mainehistory.pastperfect-online.com/32314cgi/mweb.exe?req... Fish Hawk as a derelict vessel in Noank, CT: connecticuthistoryillustrated.org/islandora/search/%22fis...
Looks like she is enjoying herself.

It looks like this ship was actually the Albatross. This photo appears in a Rockefeller Foundation publication with the caption: "Abby Aldrich Rockefeller holds the hammer that she used to drive a bolt during construction of the “Albatross” in Portland, Maine, in mid August 1918." Photograph by Underwood & Underwood, New York City www.rockarch.org/publications/newsletter/nl2000.pdf at p. 11.

Albatross built at same shipyard as Fish Hawk: Portland SB, South Portland ME, O.N. 217411 Albatross East Coast Fisheries Co Trawler GT 384 Delivery1918 Wrecked Diamond Shoals 1940 www.shipbuildinghistory.com/history/shipyards/719thcentur... Wreck: wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?236463 about the loss cause lost: ran aground (wrecked) date lost: 21/02/1940

The Evening star., September 01, 1918, Image 50 published a similar photo with the capture: "Mrs. John D. Rockefeller, jr., driving a spike into the keel of the new trawler Fish-Hawk at Portland, Me." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1918-09-01/ed-...

The evening world., August 16, 1918, Final Edition, Page 5, with another photo of the event cited by [https://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] in the Library of Congress (with the names of some of the other participating persons): chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1918-08-16/ed-...

On the other hand, The Washington times., August 19, 1918, FINAL EDITION, Page 13 published a photo of Mrs. Rockefeller driving a bolt in a keel as well, and it reported that the name of the trawler was "Albatros". chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1918-08-19/ed-...
Apparently, both trawlers were built in 1918, s. connecticuthistoryillustrated.org/islandora/object/70002%...: "Fish Hawk was built in South Portland, Maine, 1918, by Portland Shipbuilding Company."
The wikipedia entry of Abby Aldrich Rockefeller (October 26, 1874 – April 5, 1948): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abby_Aldrich_Rockefeller
An article about the end of the "Fish Hawk" at Noank Shipyard is in The Day, April 2, 1987. The pilothouse survived. news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1915&dat=19870401&...

In the 1987 newspaper article, the uncovered pilothouse inscription said the Fish Hawk was launched in August, 1918, which is in line with the references cited by Seuss, above. The article in Shipping says that by June 15th, 1918, Fish Hawk was almost ready for launching, but that only "a good start" had been made on Albatross. Assuming the pictured event was the August, 1918 visit made by Abby Rockefeller in connection with a nearby convention of the YWCA in Portland, the pictured ship (nowhere near launching), is probably the Albatross. Albatross at Noank, CT, much later: connecticuthistoryillustrated.org/islandora/object/30002%... An August, 1918 account of the event from the Charlotte, NC News: " One of the most ardent members of the Y. W. C. A. is Mrs. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. During the convention week Mrs. Rockefeller and several of the other, women delegates visited the fishing trawler "Albatross." The boat is under construction now and when finished will be equipped with all of the latest marine and fishing necessities, among them a wireless outfit. The trawler has the distinction of being the second fishing boat to be equipped with wireless. "Just to see how it felt" and to have a hand in some actual hard lbor, Mrs. Rockefeller took a huge hammer and struck a bolt in the keel of the boat. After one blow she decided that the shipyards was not the place for girls to work but that it would perhaps be a good place for some of the slackers who are hastening there." www.newspapers.com/newspage/61391496/ An account in the New York Evening Post describes the meeting as the National Woman's War Work Council and the ship as the Albatross: fultonhistory.com/highlighter/viewer/?file=http%3A%2F%2Ff...

Thanks everyone for your close look at this photograph. I agree with Art Siegel that sources and date indicate that this is the Albatross and not the Fish Hawk. We will add more details when we update.

"President Woodrow Wilson came out to Mount Vernon on several occasions. Here is a description of one visit by Colonel Harrison Howell Dodge: “President Woodrow Wilson several times honored Mount Vernon by his presence, but quite the most spectacular event in which he took part was on the Fourth of July, 1918, when he brought as his guests, on the Mayflower, fifty or more delegates representing the thousands of foreign-born citizens of the United States, wishing, by this public commemoration of our Declaration of Independence, to testify their loyalty to America. Each delegate bore a handsome wreath distinguished by his respective national colors, the collection quite filling the Tomb. “It was estimated that nearly 20,000 persons were present on that notable day: “The Star Spangled Banner” was sung by John McCormack, who insisted on being accompanied by a Steinway Grand piano. Lieut. Malcolm M. Johnstone, (1892-1918) Arlington, WA, Killed in action, France.

"LT MALCOLM M. JOHNSTONE
Arlington, Washington
Killed in Action

Lieut. Malcolm Maclaren Johnstone was the son of Robert Lorimer & Isabelle (Henderson) Johnstone, born 3 September 1892 at Savannah, Dawson Co., Georgia.  He had siblings: Henrietta, Colin, Edwin Dykes, Norman Stewart, Allen J., and Robert V.

He attended schools in Washington State, and graduated from Stadium High School, Tacoma Washington in 1912.  This followed by attending both the University of Oregon, and Columbia University in New York.

He enlisted in the Army August 15, 1917. In November 1917 he received a commission at Fort Oglethorpe, and was assigned to Camp Greene. He was sent to Europe, serving in Co. D, 2d Engineers, 2d Division.  On 3 June 1918 he was killed in action, killed by a fragment of a high explosive shell on the Chateau-Thierry front. The book, Sonomish County in the War states that his commanding officer, Captain Chisholm said: “No officer of our splendid regiment was more popular with both officers and men.”  A plaque in Arlington, Washington’s City Hall remembers his (and others) WW1 service.

He is buried at Arlington National Cemetery, Section 3, Grave: 3992-WH
+
MALCOLM M
JOHNSTONE
NEW YORK
1st LT
2 ENGRS 2 DIV
JUNE 3, 1918"

Robert Obadiah Purdy, Jr. (1891-1918) From The Watchman and Southron. (Sumter, S.C.), August 7, 1918: "SUMTER'S FIRST SACRIFICE. Lieut. Robert O. Purdy, Jr., Killed in Action July 21st [...] For days, ever since the great bat- tle on the Marne began, Sumter has been tense with dread and anxiety, fearing that the next report of cas- ualties would contain the names of some of the Sumter boys who are fighting with Pershing's men to drive the Huns out of France and turn back the wave of barbarism that for four years has been dashing against the ramparts of civilization. Late Friday afternoon the dreaded news came in a message to Judge R. O. Purdy, from the War Department, saying that Lieut. Robert O. Purdy. Jr., had been killed in action on July 21st. The message gave no particu- lars, merely the fact that one of our boys had died at the post of duty where the Americans and the French were driving the Huns back from the Marne. The news spread rapidly over the town and every home be- came a house of mourning and Judgej Purdy's personal sorrow was shared by one and all. Lieut. Purdy. was twenty-seven years old, the eldest son of Judge R. O. Purdy and was born and reared in this city, attended the city schools and afterwards the University of South Carolina, completing his law course there with the class of 1914. From his graduation until last spring he was associated with his father in the practice of law in this city, at which time he entered the first offi- cers' training camp at Fort Ogle- thorpe. He was commissioned sec- ond lieutenant of infantry and vol- unteered for immediate service in France, and after a short stay at home sailed for France early in September. He went into active service with the first American forces sent to the bat- tle front and spent the winter in the trenches. In the spring he was gassed and was in a hospital for weeks and later was assigned to duty in the rear, a few weeks ago was re-as- signed to active service with his old command, at his own request. One of the last letters received from him brought the news that he would re- turn to the firing line the next day. Robert Purdy volunteered for service not because he loved a fight or be- cause he was of an adventurous dis position eager for the excitement to be found in the army on the field of battle, but because he felt that he was called to perform a duty by his coun- try. He gave himself cheerfully with the full realization that he might probably would, have to make the su- preme sacrifice. He died at the front near the flashing of the guns with other young Americans animated by a like spirit of patriotism." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn93067846/1918-08-07/ed-... His memorial in Sumter, S.C. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=68247517 and his grave in France: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=purdy&...;

Bolted to the table is a Circular Sock Machine, specifically, an Auto-Knitter, manufactured by the AutoKnitters & Hosiery Company of Buffalo, NY from 1916-1927. Identical machines were later manufactured/sold by several companies up to the 90s. [https://www.flickr.com/photos/mikewade/3025705455/] ". . . By mid-1918 the need for socks was so severe that the Red Cross begged knitters, “Don’t make sweaters … every pound of yarn that can be secured should be used for knitting socks” " from Knitting for Victory -- World War I[https://www.flickr.com/photos/estonia76/530916797/]

"In May 1918 the Seattle School Bulletin printed this patriotic knitting song: Johnnie, get your yarn, get your yarn, get your yarn; Knitting has a charm, has a charm, has a charm, See us knitting two by two, Boys in Seattle like it too. Hurry every day, don’t delay, make it pay. Our laddies must be warm, not forlorn mid the storm. Hear them call from o’re the sea, ‘Make a sweater, please for me.’ Over here everywhere, We are knitting for the boys over there, It’s a sock or a sweater, or even better To do your bit and knit a square." www.historylink.org/index.cfm?DisplayPage=output.cfm&...

Arthur Francis Moseley (March 14, 1877 - July 5, 1918) "Arthur Francis Moseley was a pastor at the United Brethren Church in Freeport. He actually answered the call to military duty three separate times. A native of Macon, Ga., born in 1877, Moseley first enlisted in the British Army in 1900 as a 23-year-old. He served as a dispatch rider in “Brabant’s Second Horse Battalion.” He earned the “Queen’s South Africa Medal” in the Boer War. The new display includes a photo of him in the uniform of that war. In 1898, Moseley enlisted in the U.S. Army to serve in the Second Cavalry Regiment during the Spanish-American War. His unit served in Cuba. At age 40, Moseley again enlisted, this time in the Second Officer’s Training Camp at Fort Sheridan in Chicago. After being commissioned a captain, he volunteered to be sent to France during World War I and was given command of Company G, 16th Infantry Regiment, 1st Division. Moseley was killed in action on July 5, 1918, near Cantigny, France." www.journalstandard.com/article/20130804/NEWS/308049942/?... S. also en.wikisource.org/wiki/Page:The_history_and_achievements_... (with photo)

From second link above:

"CAPTAIN ARTHUR FRANCIS MOSELEY

Company G, 16th Infantry, First Division. Killed in action near Cantigny, France, on July 5, 1918.

Captain Moseley was born in Macon, Ga., on March 14, 1877. He was educated in the public schools of that city and studied for the ministry, which profession, along with writing and lecturing, he practiced until his entry into the British Army in 1900, serving during the Boer war as a despatch rider, and winning the Queen's Medal and several citations. After the South African war he joined a United States Cavalry outfit and served in the Spanish-American war in Cuba as a sergeant. Returning to civil life he again took up pulpit work, but resigned from his position to enter the Second Officers' Training Camp at Fort Sheridan when the Great War broke out. He was assigned to the Twenty-third Company. Upon receiving his commission he was ordered overseas, sailing in December, 1917. After further instruction in France, Captain Moseley was assigned to the 16th Infantry, with which regiment he met instant death on July 5, 1918, near Cantigny. Captain Moseley was twice married. Besides his widow, Mrs. Lily M. Moseley, of Freeport, Ill., he is survived by four children. Grey, aged 22; Lily M., aged 13; Francis D., aged 12; and Oliver I., aged 10 years, and his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Moseley, of Macon, Ga."
